content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												100% Orange Juice is a board game developed by the Japanese indie developer Orange_Juice, and features the cast from all their previous games. I personally put of buying the game because I thought I'd need to know the characters, but after playing the game I realized that knowledge wasn't necessary. As for the game itself, it is described by many as really hard, mainly because of how much it uses RNG to determine outcomes. I do however think that this builds into one of the game's main strengths. Because while luck is important, just as important is your ability to manipulate that luck using the cards that you're given. And that leads me to another very interesting mechanic of the game. Because the game is also a deckbuilding game. Every player creates a deck of 10 cards, and then all the decks created are shuffled together, and it's this pile of cards the players draw from. This creates strategic choices where you have choose the cards that are good for your character, but not good for the other characters.All in all, I think 100% OJ is a great game that anyone who's interested in board games should try out.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												Board games are fun, but whenever I played Monopoly with my friends, we’d always give up playing midway through. The reason for that is quite simple – after some time, most of the board games get repetitive, and if they take too long to end, you’ll get bored and you’re likely to lose your will to keep playing. Despite it all, I've heard so many people saying good things about 100% OJ and the game itself seemed so interesting that I decided to put aside my uncertainties and give the game a shot. The moment I pressed the play button, my fate was sealed.100% OJ got me hooked because each play will never be the same and it never gets boring, no matter how much or how long you play it. It’s a game played on an ever-changing environment where you can either battle your way through victory or try to grasp it while aiming for the stars – the choice is yours! You won’t even notice it doesn’t have a story to go along with it because it’s not necessary – that’s not why we’re here anyways! Besides, the best part is playing against your friends or other players online.11/10

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												A guide to making 100% orange juice.1. First off you start off pouring 50% rage mix into an empty glass. No doubt that this will be the most important ingredient; however, this is my personal preference. Feel free to add more or less to it.2. Next, we have pour 15% moe sauce into the glass. Don't judge me.3. 5% pudding. Optional unless you're serving it to a dog girl.4. 20% stars. The exact amount of stars might very, but if you want to come out on top, you're going to need at least 200.5. 5% tears. It shouldn't be too hard to produce your own, especially since you're so close to finishing it.6. Get on your knees and pray to RNGesus that he allows you to transcend into godhood upon consuming this juice. If he hears your prayer, he'll reward you with the final 5% so that your orange juice will taste like VICTORY.7. Cry in agony as Marie Poppo steals your stars that you worked so hard to obtain.8. Beat the living♥♥♥♥♥♥out of her until she gives every. single. one. back.9. Produce a terrifying, yet slightly attractive, evil laugh.10. Realize that you wasted far too much time trying to make that laugh sound more attractive. Because of that, Marc had already made her orange juice before you.11. Throw the current glass at Marc's ugly face.12. Grab a new glass.13. Remember when I told you to pour 50% rage mix? Screw that, you're going full 100% rage.14. Pick Star Breaker and beat the living♥♥♥♥♥♥out of not just Poppo and Marc, but every potential waifu and husbando from 3 different game universes because you're practically insane at this point.Anyway enough but making my guide to making orange juice. Time for the actual game review:Yeah, it's pretty fun. Buy it.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
TL;DRI like the game, good price, RNG hates you, fun with friends every now and then if you like the board game style ProsAdjustable speed settingsMusicBrutalConsSounds Gameplay I like the game, honestly. It's fun to play and quite brutal in the fact a match is a mix of different playstles and objectives, mixed with luck/RNG. The way to win a game is to complete objectives, or Norma. The objectives are either to collect stars, and you can choose to play passively like this, or to defeat enemies/monsters on the board, so a more aggressive play-style. Stars is a safer style but you run the risk of losing half your stars on being knocked unconscious, and playing aggressive is riskier but more fast paced if you spend the game hunting things down and killing them. (And make everyone else annoyed with you and consequently revenge hunt.) You can defend attacks and take a set amount of damage, or evade to take no damage, or tank the full amount if you fail to dodge.Luck is not going to always be on your side, especially with the traps and events set around the board. But ah well.It's simple mechanics that can be massively sped up if you want a faster paced game, and I like that, especially as I can get bored fast if I have to spend too much time on the turns or waiting for my turn. Graphics are chibi anime style, nothing special but cute enough.Deceivingly cute when that adorable dog girl is beating you unconscious.I like the game but I wouldn't want to play it for too long. The sounds are ok, but if you hear them happening throughout the duration of a game it gets fast annoying, so I would honestly prefer to play without sound. However the music you can leave on in my opinion. Want moar? Click here to join my steam group and Click here to follow my curator page!

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
100% Orange Juice ReviewWhat kind of game is this? How do you play? What do you do?100% orange juice is a bored game with trading card elements. You move around the board trying to complete one of two task, killing others or gathering stars. You gather/lose stars by landing on spaces and rolling a die. You kill people by rolling a die to attack, and defend. You collect a portion of their stars if you kill them. Cards play a role by allowing you to build decks. You will draw a card from yor deck every time you land on a specific space. Cards can deal damage, give stat buffs, of be hidden traps on spaces.Controls This game is controlled entirely by the mouse; it works just fine. 10/10SoundThe game sounds fine and the voice acting is pretty good, with options to change the voice, or turn it off. 10/10 Graphics The game is not graphically intensive, and will run fine on almost any machine. The game has no 3D sprites, but looks great anyway. 10/10Difficulty The difficulty is not regulated too well. It has options, but when it comes down to it, it’s an RNG determining your fate half the time. 6/10Story The story doesn’t matter at all. The game has several story lines for each character. None of them are fantastic, but they don’t need to be. 7/10Multiplayer The game works well in online multiplayer, it is the ideal way to play. 10/10Overall this game is a great multiplayer experience, but you can play single player to grind for new cards and got some practice. (Learning how to play cards and where you should go next in your play style.) This game gets an 8/10. Strongly Recommended, especially with friends.

It's fun to play and quite brutal in the fact a match is a mix of different playstles and objectives, mixed with luck/RNG. The way to win a game is to complete objectives, or Norma. The objectives are either to collect stars, and you can choose to play passively like this, or to defeat enemies/monsters on the board, so a more aggressive play-style. Stars is a safer style but you run the risk of losing half your stars on being knocked unconscious, and playing aggressive is riskier but more fast paced if you spend the game hunting things down and killing them. (And make everyone else annoyed with you and consequently revenge hunt.) You can defend attacks and take a set amount of damage, or evade to take no damage, or tank the full amount if you fail to dodge.Luck is not going to always be on your side, especially with the traps and events set around the board. But ah well.It's simple mechanics that can be massively sped up if you want a faster paced game, and I like that, especially as I can get bored fast if I have to spend too much time on the turns or waiting for my turn. Graphics are chibi anime style, nothing special but cute enough.Deceivingly cute when that adorable dog girl is beating you unconscious.I like the game but I wouldn't want to play it for too long. The sounds are ok, but if you hear them happening throughout the duration of a game it gets fast annoying, so I would honestly prefer to play without sound. However the music you can leave on in my opinion. Want moar? Click here to join my steam group and Click here to follow my curator page!

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												If you're into the whole 'Kawaii-Ness' of japanese chibi characters, then this game is already worth it.Despite having gotten it during the summer 2014 steam sale, I would of easily bought this at its' full price, due to the fun and interest in the game.The game itself is basically a form of board game where you have to complete tasks (normas) either by getting 'stars' (granted by either the end of a 'chapter' by defeating a CPU, Player, or Flash Enemy, or by landing on a bonus tile), or by getting wins (granted by defeating a CPU, Player, or Flash Enemy).You're allowed to start of as four different characters (Sugure, QP, Kai, and Marc) and progress through their campaigns, which allows you to amass star points, which can then be used to unlock other characters which are unlocked for buying through the campaigns. Each character has a different specialty in terms of skills (Attack, Defense, and Evasion) and each have different hypers (Unique skills that attune to a specific character, an example being Marc's 16x Big Cannon, which damages a specific character in attunement with how many 'star levels' that Marc has.)Overall, the game is filled with kawaii, board games, a little bit of friendly murderous rivalry, and a lot of fun.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												Welcome to Orange Juice's Board game where you and your friends (or imaginary friends if you dont have them) can have a fun time playing a game of diceBefore i say anything... This is actually a crossover game between their already existing games like "flying red barrel", "Suguri" , "QP shooting" and some others i probably dont remember but now onto the review100% orange juice is like i said a board game made by orange juice and localised by Fruit Bat FactorySo the first time you look at it you are probably thinking "hey this look like fortune street and or mario party" but this game uses a stars and card system much like mario party's items and coins but rather than trying to collect as many stars you can you have to "level up" your norma level... how would you do that you ask? you can level up the first time by gaining 10 stars and further down a line pick between battling and collecting more stars but im sorry if you are reading this since i have a hard time not explaining everythingthis game allows you to create a deck of a few cards that do various things as well as use character that all have various stats and plenty of campaigns to go through. as i havent beaten my first campaign yet there are 4 characters you can pick from to start with each of them having some sort of penalty and buff to themselves as well as their own hyper card which are mixed into the deck (hyper cards can only be drawn by their specific character but if you draw a hyper card the other players will have a lower chance of drawing one themselves) you can obtain said cards by earning stars by winning or losing a game and buying packs of cards much like a trading card game and before you ask... there is no such thing as trading but... you can trade the cards you earn on steam... that counts right?so you heard me mention about statsin this game rather than mini games you get battles as i mentioned before being one of the requirements you can pick to level upso in battles you have 3 base stats atk, def and evasion and you each get to roll your dice once (unless a card says so otherwise) the player who starts the battle goes first and has roll for atk if you roll a 6 you have a 6 hit atk simple as that but the second player defending is able to defend or evade if you defend the same thing as atk applies if you roll a 6 you take only 1 damage but if you choose to evade you can negate the damage completely by rolling higher than the amount of atk but if you roll lower than the atk you take the full damage ofcourse the stats on your characters are applies to these actions if you have +1 atk you get you dice result +1 as the same thing counts for defence and evasionbut enough talking about how the game plays out because im pretty sure i confused you all enough and explained too much about the gamethe game in general can be pretty pretty hard depending on your dice rolls and the a.i is going to try and take you down and each character follows a specific pattern or behaviour and tends to try and prevent you from winning as much as you canthanks to the localization team the online of this game is improved by alot compared to its original releasebecause in the english version you have lobbies that are supported by steam and makes it alot easier to set something up with your friends and maybe even strangers and online you get to level up and earn exp which was never implemented in the original gamein general i really think you should get this game if you like board gamesits a fun game and it doesnt take itself seriouslyif i ruined the game for you i take all responsibility but dont hate me for it... hey maybe if your lucky you will bump into me online

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												++My Way Of Thinking When I Play Games++"Now that we have countless games to try, we do not experience the same feeling of having a game for ourselves, and nothing else than that, that is why we find the negative aspects quicker than when we were young, games were fun, even the now called ''Bad Games''. If you give this game a try, do not be afraid and play it like you did when you were young."++Quick Intro Containing Information Of How Much This Game Means To Me++Before I give my opinion of this game, I really have to go back to when I was a child, you would ask, why?. . . Well It is quite obvious that as you can see, one first look at this game it could remind you of Mario Party.I only played Mario Party 1, 2 and 3 when I was a kid, but that doesn't really matter here, or does it?. In fact, it kind of does, because when I first saw this game I felt like it was Mario Party, but with Weird anime girl and probably some P. . .Things that could scare anyone who's not into this or not even into anime. But, I once saw this game discounted 75% OFF, I said to myself "Okay I'll try it and then if I dislike it I will instantly refund it". . . Oh how wrong was I the whole time. . .This game became part of my life as on how easy it is to connect with people, spectate, join as the match is currently being played, and the community, funny as hell, and well, this game got me so happy that I bought it 8 TIMES, now why did I buy it 8 times you ask?. . . I bought it so my friends could play with me. 7 out of 8 loved it and we still play it these days. Now, again what did I do or say that got me into this game?.++Important Words That Got Me Into Playing This Game++I cleared my mind and said to myself "let's try something new", now why I was able to do this?, mostly because of the new steam Refunds that you can now refund any game quickly without losing anything, which is a great feature I am really glad they added it!.++The Review++//Positive Aspects\\ Have you ever heard of Jonathan The Seagull? - You will after you play this game "7"[+] The gameplay of this game is quite great, each character has their Pros and Cons, as in my opinion everything is quite balanced, you are not forced to play a certain character or pick a certain card as everything is usually RANDOM, so it's not a game that you have to always win or you will be thinking of winning. That is why these are the 10 Pros I could find in this game~.1[+] As  I said earlier, 100% Orange Juice has a great Multiplayer, that you can easily join anyone's match while playing, specate, straight up join as a random character that is currenlty playing and well as a cards game, you will not have lag. It's  in my opinion the perfect casual game you can try on Steam.2[+] If you are into Anime you'll find some of these characters funny or cute as they all have their wacky stories in story mode, plus some of them come from different games from the Developer Orange_Juice, if you want more detailed story, you can play the other games where those Wacky Characters appear.3[+] In order to unlock some Characters you will need to finish the story mode, which is. . . not the main appeal of the game, don't worry, I will add this to the Cons, but why do I place this here?. Well it is because there's a fast forward button that let's you just click and hope for the best to be able to complete it as soon as possible [Ctrl + Shift], even they knew that the Story Mode was going to suck so they added that.4[+] Everyone has their own way of playing, you can either choose Stars or Battles:A: Each Character has Stars, which are won by stopping by Yellow Panels to earn some depending on the Dice you throw, you Throw 6 , you get 6 Stars. Which help you to level up if you are aiming for StarsB: If you dislike playing like this, you can test your luck in Battles, and earn "Battle Points", each time you step on a Red Panel you will have to fight a Minion, they are quite tough, so you need a proper character to face them sometimes, or you can aim for the other Characters instead, and if you win you Earn 2 Wins instead of 1.5[+] There's so many ways to play this game, and I will try not to spoiler you the ones I use because they are kind of tricky.6[+]Each Character has their own Unique Stats like:A: They all have their Attack - Defense and Evasive stats, that makes your Dice change depending on how much you have on those, suppose if you are attacking, if you throw the dice and it shows that you got a 6. And you have +2 of Attack, your dice will do 8 of AttackB: They all have their own "Ultimate Cards", that difference each other from the rest, one throws a card that Upgrades your Character so you can throw 2 Dices for a Round, the other one steals Stars from your enemies, and so onC: And who could forget the ones that have like 7 HP. . .7[+] Some of the Skins that you could but, that dress your Character differently are purchased in the game with Money that you receive in online matches or in the story mode.8[+] The game is so quick that you won't care if you lose, as long as you have a blast and make some friends!~.9[+] The soundtrack is AWESOME for some characters10[+] THE MOST IMPORTANT ONE: The community helped me understand how the game works, as there isn't any tutorial that explains you everything, it is a great feeling when you are part of that community, and you can teach anyone you see that is having a hard time.//Negative Aspects\\ YOU RUINED MY SONG I WILL KILL YOU![-] Now I don't think this game is for everyone, as you could only play games to win, or seriously, I would recommend you to skip this one, if you are someone in that side. You will get frustated at these things:1[-] Sometimes you are winning and having a streak in your game , but suddenly you step on a card that demolishes your HP to 1. . .someone kills you and then you lose all your stars and they win. And you are like "It's fine". . .2[-] Some characters have to be purchased as DLC, they aren't strong but they add mix to the game, honestly this game feels like It is worth $15 so I am not really angry to see that there are these many DLCs, plus they  are $1 each when they are Discounted. . . well some of them3[-] You will dislike it at first as the game pretty much doesn't explain you anything, at all, the community in this game HAS TO4[-] Sometimes you are listening to some character's soundtrack when they level up and then boom. . .that music is gone because someone else leveled up5[-] Some people play in Normal Speed, as you will find it quite slooow compared to the Really Fast one, if you are the one playing all the time in that oneOverall: I am honestly running out of ideas of what else could be wrong at this game, becase everything that I said I think it wasn't that bad at all, you can easily ignore all the bad things I said and jump into a match, as I can honestly tell that you are going to have a blast in one match, as you won't be able to stop playing. It really is a great game that I have found, and I'm so happy that I had to dedicate it a Serious Review, it really feels unique and fun. If you are a fan of Casual Games, then consider giving a try to this game!~.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												This game is basically RNG incarnate, but, it still has major strategical choices such as which paths to take which battles to avoid and when to save and use your cards which alter the outcome of the game, HOWEVER, the entirety of the game is based on your movement and ability with the dice therefore it is entirely possible you are beaten by a chicken even though you're the strongest character in the game *cough*Tomomo/Sherry*cough*.The game has a strategic element of deckbuilding <however your cards are mixed with ALL the other players cards in the center deck for all to draw! so each character's deck should be the most advantageous to you while being disadvantageous to others if possible.>, to add to that each character <aside from enemy characters> have a unique hyper ability which is what the characters are generally built around, For example, the hyper ability of Alte is such that it is able to be deployed in battle, if you lose that battle(Alte), you self destruct, you permantnely gain +1 atk for the remainder of the match up to a maximum of 3, which is an incredibly high attack value and if achieved the highest of any playable character to consistently have... In addition some characters play more uniquely, such as Mixed Poppo who is able to gain abilities based on her level and landing on a warp panel... overall all the characters feel and play uniquely and none feel too gimmicky, other than the playable enemy characters[non boss, like chicken, roboball and seagull who just have baseline weak stats and no real special abilities to speak of.]I wholly recommend this game and all of its dlc, you'll have a blast, even if you just play with public groups, the community in this game is great, plus communication isn't necessarily key, so  you can have fun even when the game room is quiet, the soundtrack is also great, each character has their own unique soundtrack and there really isn't one thing I can think of that is a fault for this game, it's truly the best original board game on steam, don't pass it up just because of the anime graphics... there's a deep game underneath the cute exterior that has hundreds of hours of replayability with all the dlc and possibilities.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												My new favorite board game. Also, a lackluster TCG and fast-paced RPG.Do not be fooled by the cutesy graphics. This is a very well-developed game.Starting with the trading card game elements, there aren't very many cards and there's no trading. Still, this game uses a rather clever solution for balance: each player picks a handful of cards from their own collection and those get put into a communal deck to be used by any player. When selecting cards, you have to weigh the value of how much it can help you if you get it against the impact of it being used by another player. Card types include "boost," "trap," "battle," and "unit" cards.On the RPG side of things, there are a few selectable characters who each have their own short, comedic story, but these stories aren't really focused on enough to be factored into the decision to purchase the game. Each character has different stats; one has +0 to all stats while another has +2 attack and -1 defense and evasion while yet another has +1 to all while having reduced HP. These stats can only be changed temporarily by using cards; there are no stat level ups, which helps keep things from getting too imbalanced. Having low values for all these stats helps make combat go faster. The stats are added to the value of die rolls to determine damage, and when you only have ~5 max HP, every point matters. Each character also has their own unique "hyper" ability that is activated by cards in the communal deck.During combat, the attacker rolls first. The defender then chooses whether to defend or attempt to evade. After the aggressor's attack, the victim then counterattacks with the same mechanics if they were not slain.While the characters do not gain experience, stats, or abilities, you (the player) do. Each match played online gives experience based on how well you ended up doing and level ups unlock more stuff to purchase in the shop including more characters.The boardgame mixes strategy with luck. There's enough luck involved that a player who is down is not truly out until the game's finished, and a player with a large lead is not safe until landing on the finish. I've seen many examples of come-from-behind victories and large leads falling to pieces, and these ups and downs help keep the game fun and interesting when playing with other players. As far as strategy goes, you can pick routes when the path branches (altering the distance to home), you pick when to play cards, and when passing another player you can choose to stop on their square and battle them with victory awarding you half their stars and +2 win points. The goal of the game is to meet an ever increasing goal of either stars or combat wins (player's choice) and reach a home point to turn in that goal (and thus reach the next goal tier, with 5 being the final tier, earning victory when cleared). Wins always go up but can be difficult to get while stars are easier to earn yet just as easy to lose. There are also plenty of boards with very different layouts which helps the game stay fun after multiple play sessions.The game is mostly suited for online play (though it does have a single player campaign and free mode), and it has a few things of note in that area. The game uses Steam servers to form lobbies and you can have a match with random players. During a normal turn, you get 60 seconds before the AI takes over for you, so it's not too much of a problem if players leave their keyboard for a bit. When attacked, you are given 40 seconds to decide what to do, but the other player's clock freezes after they make a choice, so you can't outwait them for the sake of taking advantage of enemy AI. When doing a revival roll, you are given less time.Addtionally, Fruitbat Factory has been quite active in the community as well as busy adding content and rebalancing things.Verdict:The game looks quirky enough that I wouldn't normally recommend it, but it makes for one heck of a cheap party game. If you and up to 3 friends are looking for a casual game to play online in which all players remain on equal ground and can get this cheap, it comes highly recommended. If you do not have 3 friends, bots or random players will fill in the missing spots.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												100% guaranteed to turn you into a masochist.You will play.You will rage.You will make bad rolls.You will not find the RNG God is with you.You will lose all your friends.You will become addicted and find out, to your horror, that you cannot stop....And you will LIKE IT!10/10 will need rehab.----------------Seriously, though, this game is amazing.  While some audiences might be put off by certain aspects of this game's "cover", the game itself is actually very fun with replay value through the roof!  The game is balanced, well-developed, and surprisingly deep.  While RNG elements are very prevalent in this game, there is a certain amount of skill introduced with the cards, battle system, and choosing your path on the board (ie. where to go, who to fight, and whether or not to stop at home).  The battle system is simple, yet not any more or less so than necessary.  The characters are all balanced and the varying stats between them is a welcome difference as compared to Mario Party.  The multiplayer is only lacking because there aren't enough people playing this game yet (which needs to change).  But the people there so far are amazing.  I hop into the middle of a game as a spectator and made a new friends before even becoming a player (and it wasn't a random FR, for the record).Everything balances out in terms of randomness and difficulty.  You'll find yourself having days where you can't win anything, and then you'll bne like me where you win 3 MP games in a row as Yuki, then come in second to Yuki on Tomomo's board, only to win against Tomomo the following round and feel like a lumberjacking boss.  Anyone can win/lose to anyone else.  No two games ever wind up the same, and even the DLC is balanced.More constant fun than many games give you for significantly less than any AAA title on the market.Seriously, 10/10.  Would rage buy agian.  (Probably will; it'd make a Nice Present for my friends.)But Tomomo is stll a trucking pain in the donkey.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Here's a bit of what you can expect from the game:Good multiplayer chance game, with strategic elements (especially the cards: you can put a quarter of the 40 cards in the deck). Pretty fun, pretty anger inducing, mostly for single-player where the game is rigged to make it more challenging (bad method, in my opinion). With the latest 1.7 update, things are looking pretty good, with some character customization (visual), difficulty levels, more drop-ables in multiplayer, saving decks per character, and other fixes. Game could definitely use some pop-up help info on some things, but you'll get it as you go anyhow. Those who are less-skilled definitely have a chance at winning, which is good news for some, and according to one self-proclaimed such person, chance makes it less anger-inducing when they lose, so your mileage will vary on that. At least 11 characters not counting enemy/boss playable characters (Final boss is bannable) make for some decent variety, each with dice-roll-altering stats, and a special "Hyper" card that individualizes to them on draw (though if hands get randomized, shenanigans can happen). Seems fairly balanced, though I'm still relatively new (I've beat 2/4 campaigns and 1/4 "extra" stages at this point, multiplayer level 11).  Play at a higher game speed for mplay, as the timer currently runs out while your character is moving around and such, and the timer is unaffected by the speed. Get the 4-pack, as it's great to have people you know involved.[Compatibility: One issue with this latest patch is that the user.dat file format has increased in size over 10x, probably making it no longer compatible with non-steam versions (I have both) via transferring to the old non-steam version. I was previously bringing that file with my profile in it over to the old version to play with someone who apparently has difficulties with the steam mplay user interface.]

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												I originally received 100% Orange from a friend who wanted to try out the multiplayer system, and wanted to take advantage of the system to troll me. I obliged, and lost horribly the first game I played because I didn't read the instructions. This is not to say I have gotten much better, but the game has definetly grown on me, even if in the process I have been killed by seagulls, chickens, every single boss, my friend, bombs, and (possibly worst of all) AI Poppo. Praise the almighty randomness. If you could get the achievement for failing to revive in the final roll more than once, I would have gotten it multiple times already.This is a surprisingly fun game to play with other people, and I ended up getting it for a couple other friends (on sale, granted). One thing to keep in mind is that it is probably better not to play it after you had a bad day, as you can either be blessed by the dice or not. And, needless to say, the random nature of the game (and how quickly you can go from the lead to the bottom) will definetly be enjoyed by some, but hated by others. Keep in mind that, ultimately, the same seagull that you cheered on as they defeated your competition, might one day kill you too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												If you want to play this game, and you should, you better be a forgiving person.RNG is going to ♥♥♥♥ you over so many times you'll never want to drink orange juice again due to the PTSD you'll have gotten from this game.Soon all hope of ever achieving anything will evaporate from your life.The game will play cheery music as you roll 2's every time you get KO'ed so you can't get revived.The AI will use boost cards that get them to 10+ attack so you can't really do anything to survive.Somehow they will always roll what they need in order to land on the home tile.And if you do somehow win, just know that every level you progress in a campaign, the more the cute characters want you to fail.This game is 20% skill, 10% luck and 70% RNG bias against you.Rather, we should rename this game "100% NotWhatYouWantedToRoll"Anyways, it is a whole lot of fun, and muliplayer is good too. If you don't like the RNG bias, then play the campaigns on casual. You'll have a great time, I promise.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												This game is hard to explain to people who haven't heard or seen it before. It is a very, very luck based board game, in which you kill your opponents and enemies in order to gain wins and stars. Get enough of either, and you can win. Despite being very luck based, it still has a bit of skill and strategy throughout the game. Using various cards and judgement, you can sway the game in your favor just so slightly. The visuals of the game are very pleasing, nothing looks terrible. The music is amazing, especially some of the DLC characters. It may not be a game for everyone, but it is a game you can love (and hate at times) with friends.And you will die. To seagulls. A lot. (Other enemies/characters, but mostly seagulls. Not even kidding)I suggest if you haven't played this game, at least give the demo a go. A fun game that has lots of replayability, especially with friends. You never know what will happen in any specific game of 100% Orange Juice.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												I originally received 100% Orange from a friend who wanted to try out the multiplayer system, and wanted to take advantage of the system to troll me. I obliged, and lost horribly the first game I played because I didn't read the instructions. This is not to say I have gotten much better, but the game has definetly grown on me, even if in the process I have been killed by seagulls, chickens, every single boss, my friend, bombs, and (possibly worst of all) AI Poppo. Praise the almighty randomness. If you could get the achievement for failing to revive in the final roll more than once, I would have gotten it multiple times already.This is a surprisingly fun game to play with other people, and I ended up getting it for a couple other friends (on sale, granted). One thing to keep in mind is that it is probably better not to play it after you had a bad day, as you can either be blessed by the dice or not. And, needless to say, the random nature of the game (and how quickly you can go from the lead to the bottom) will definetly be enjoyed by some, but hated by others. Keep in mind that, ultimately, the same seagull that you cheered on as they defeated your competition, might one day kill you too.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												The reason Steam needs an "ehhhhhh" option for recommendations is games like this.-Are you a weeaboo? Like, body pillow of Homura Akemi, Naruto headband and box of Pocky level of weeaboo? Then you'll like this game despite everything following this. OMG SO KAWAII DESU NE XDD SUGOI-AI is rigged often and you need to trap card them if you want to win (This is a game where AI difficulty = AI's luck increased, so they will ALWAYS have their best card and will almost ALWAYS roll 5+ if they're not Mariepoppo)-Don't go into this game for BIOWARE KWALETEE STORYTELLING because there is none to be found. Every character could be summed up accurately in a -dere or just one other trope. They appear to be from other games, but I don't think anyone in the West (including myself) understands where they're from. It feels similar to having Opa-Opa in Sonic and Sega All-Stars Racing, because essentially no one knows who the hell he is.-Some characters are legitimately just way better than others, stat-wise. For example, there's that chick that the game literally WANTS you to ban if you're making an online game. Speaking of online...-Online is glitchy and incomplete, but believe hard enough and the matches will show up. If you can't host and you're playing with a friend, you might have to make them do it.-Actually, the game is better with other people rather than AI in general.-Art style feels like every anime trope drawn like they're from my 6th grade sketchbook, but not necessarily ugly like A Valley Without Wind. Poorly drawn but not like you can't look at it, reminds me of keychains in a convention's artist alley.-While the text is translated, all the audio is voiced by a KAWAII DESU NE japanese girl in sort-of-english, so if that bugs you, don't go for this game.-PRO TIP: Holding shift speeds up the AI's turns. You will need this so you don't have to watch Mariepoppo get her♥♥♥♥♥kicked by chickens repeatedly.-If you want to buy this game because it has cards, I'm gonna need you to rethink your life choices.Overall, Waifu Party 8 is playable and mildly amusing, but you could just play Monopoly instead. Even if you want a digital board game, Mario Party is more skill-based than this (with most minigames requiring some kind of skill). It's not something you should pick up while it's not on sale, or if you don't like Yu-Gi-Oh with catgirls. Glad I got it as a gift.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												First and foremost I want everyone reading this to know that if you don't have friends to play with, or friends that you wouldn't play mario party with (for the sake of friendships not burning into piles of ashes), you probably shouldn't get this game. The single player is fun and all, but usually tipped in the ai's favour, which can be a fun-spoiler sometimes. That said, I've played both campaign and multiplayer, campaign to an extent and multiplayer quite a bit, and overall I'd totally recommend this to people who have others to play it with. Pick up the four-pack while it's on sale. Or while it's not on sale, it's still a pretty good deal. Into the actual game, this one is a board game in a party style. There are a lot of characters with unique 'hyper' (character-specific, usually pretty cool) cards. These characters are from Orange Juice's other games, and it's a very colourful cast with pretty good character design. The art style is cute, and the game is moderately easy to learn, save for some confusion if you don't read at least the basics of the game's guide (which has its own option to pick on the menu screen when you select/create your profile, so you really don't have an excuse to skip out on that unless you just want to yolo it). It's fairly simplistic, but in the best way I can mean it. Too much complexity can ruin a party game like this. It has a lot of maps to unlock and check out, and a large diversity of cards, a long with some interesting strategies to pull once you've got the hang of it. Like any game with a lot of characters like this, not all of them are perfectly balanced, so be aware of that.Overall, I'd give it a 8/10 for what it is, and only really taking off the two points for the cheating AI in campaign and the (kind of) tedious process of unlocking new characters to play (which involves campaign). I really love this game, and I'm glad to have it.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Really, this game should win every award.Test of Time: This is a game that's very random, and due to a lot of various luck-based events, no match will be the same. On top of that, new DLC gets released every couple of months or so, and really help add to the game's content.I'm Not Crying, There's Something In my Eye: Man, when QP FINALLY got her pudding back, I couldn't help but cry. Okay, Marc's ending was also adorable, too.Five More Minutes: I could relist the reasons listed for why it deserves the Test of Time award, but I won't.Whoooaaaaaaa, dude!: Admit it, you didn't expect Tomomo to be the creator of the world and everyone in it.Villain Most In Need Of A Hug: Really, in some of Tomomo's cutscenes, the protagonists are bigger villains than her. She just wants someone to play with her...Game Within A Game: ...Do player-made minigames count?I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award: I thought this game was cool before any of the DLC packs came out, and I still think it's cool to this day.Best Use Of A Farm Animal: Marie Poppo. Need I say more?And of course, I could name a million other awards it could win. "Best Multiplayer Game" and "Cutest Characters Ever" come to mind...Really, 100% Orange Juice is a wonderful game, and if it wins an award that would be awesome.#100%OrangeJuiceForEveryAwardEver

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												100% guaranteed to turn you into a masochist.You will play.You will rage.You will make bad rolls.You will not find the RNG God is with you.You will lose all your friends.You will become addicted and find out, to your horror, that you cannot stop....And you will LIKE IT!10/10 will need rehab.----------------Seriously, though, this game is amazing.  While some audiences might be put off by certain aspects of this game's "cover", the game itself is actually very fun with replay value through the roof!  The game is balanced, well-developed, and surprisingly deep.  While RNG elements are very prevalent in this game, there is a certain amount of skill introduced with the cards, battle system, and choosing your path on the board (ie. where to go, who to fight, and whether or not to stop at home).  The battle system is simple, yet not any more or less so than necessary.  The characters are all balanced and the varying stats between them is a welcome difference as compared to Mario Party.  The multiplayer is only lacking because there aren't enough people playing this game yet (which needs to change).  But the people there so far are amazing.  I hop into the middle of a game as a spectator and made a new friends before even becoming a player (and it wasn't a random FR, for the record).Everything balances out in terms of randomness and difficulty.  You'll find yourself having days where you can't win anything, and then you'll bne like me where you win 3 MP games in a row as Yuki, then come in second to Yuki on Tomomo's board, only to win against Tomomo the following round and feel like a lumberjacking boss.  Anyone can win/lose to anyone else.  No two games ever wind up the same, and even the DLC is balanced.More constant fun than many games give you for significantly less than any AAA title on the market.Seriously, 10/10.  Would rage buy agian.  (Probably will; it'd make a Nice Present for my friends.)But Tomomo is stll a trucking pain in the donkey.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												100% Orange Juice is a game that when you look at it, seems very similar to Mario Party. In a sense, it is. You collect Stars and cards in order to help you progress through the game. You roll a dice and move around the board and land on a space that has various effects ranging from you to collecting stars or cards, to losing stars and fighting enemies. Now, that's where the similarities end really. 100% OJ is by far more rutheless than Mario Party. Maybe it's just my luck, but even on normal the cpus are brutal and out for blood. If you make one wrong move, or if the game decides it hates you then you can very well go from a blazing lead to being in dead last within the span of a few turns. Now, despite that, the game itself is a lot of fun. Sure, it's a board game with goals that range from collecting a certain amount of stars, knocking out a certain amount of people or a combination of the both. The game has only 3 modes really, campaign, single matches and multiplayer. Now with any board game, playing with friends is what makes it really shine a bit more. You can play with up to three other friends, using whatever characters you unlocked, making a deck of x amount of cards and then you're put into a board, fighting or running for your life (depending on your play style and character as all characters have different stats.) in order to gain first prize. Now, with all three game modes you ear stars (which are this games currency to buy items from the store.) But only in multiplayer can you gain exp to level up and unlock new items to purchase and the sort, which the game has a decent amount of. Honestly, I suggest giving the demo a try to get a feel for the game, then convince some friends to get the game as well or find some people that would want to play. All in all, it's a fun game but can be frustrating.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												This game is very, very cute.  It's also surprisingly deep, for what appears to be a simple game on the surface.  The deck-building system and the card packs are an interesting form of advancement that seems to scream microtransaction heaven, but strangely, this game doesn't opt for that route.I'm not entirely sure there's a valid comparison to other video-board-games, because most of the mechanics are simpler and more lean.  It may be fair to call it Dokapon Kingdom X-tra Lite, since it involves collecting a "currency" and simplified and protracted combat.  The actual style of the combat reminds me of Sonic Shuffle, and the overall flow of the game feels more traditional than most.I'd buy this for $10, and it's on sale right now for $2.93.  I highly recommend it!

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												Basically a PC version of Mario Party.  100% Orange Juice holds a lot of key elements from the Mario Party series: A multitude of swears because of the RNG, the shattering and destruction of long-term friendships and yet, still plenty of hilarious moments with those "ex"-friends. content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												One part frustrating, one part fun, and one part pure ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ luck, and you've got 100% Orange Juice. In many ways, it's your typical roll of the dice game. Roll dice to move around the board and take down the HP of the other players to WIN. In many other ways, it is so much more than that. There are cards out there that will both please and frustrate you and players you will not want to go up against. The graphics are cute, the music is cute, and it is perfectly easy to get lost in this game for hours at a time. I love it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												The reason Steam needs an "ehhhhhh" option for recommendations is games like this.-Are you a weeaboo? Like, body pillow of Homura Akemi, Naruto headband and box of Pocky level of weeaboo? Then you'll like this game despite everything following this. OMG SO KAWAII DESU NE XDD SUGOI-AI is rigged often and you need to trap card them if you want to win (This is a game where AI difficulty = AI's luck increased, so they will ALWAYS have their best card and will almost ALWAYS roll 5+ if they're not Mariepoppo)-Don't go into this game for BIOWARE KWALETEE STORYTELLING because there is none to be found. Every character could be summed up accurately in a -dere or just one other trope. They appear to be from other games, but I don't think anyone in the West (including myself) understands where they're from. It feels similar to having Opa-Opa in Sonic and Sega All-Stars Racing, because essentially no one knows who the hell he is.-Some characters are legitimately just way better than others, stat-wise. For example, there's that chick that the game literally WANTS you to ban if you're making an online game. Speaking of online...-Online is glitchy and incomplete, but believe hard enough and the matches will show up. If you can't host and you're playing with a friend, you might have to make them do it.-Actually, the game is better with other people rather than AI in general.-Art style feels like every anime trope drawn like they're from my 6th grade sketchbook, but not necessarily ugly like A Valley Without Wind. Poorly drawn but not like you can't look at it, reminds me of keychains in a convention's artist alley.-While the text is translated, all the audio is voiced by a KAWAII DESU NE japanese girl in sort-of-english, so if that bugs you, don't go for this game.-PRO TIP: Holding shift speeds up the AI's turns. You will need this so you don't have to watch Mariepoppo get her♥♥♥♥♥kicked by chickens repeatedly.-If you want to buy this game because it has cards, I'm gonna need you to rethink your life choices.Overall, Waifu Party 8 is playable and mildly amusing, but you could just play Monopoly instead. Even if you want a digital board game, Mario Party is more skill-based than this (with most minigames requiring some kind of skill). It's not something you should pick up while it's not on sale, or if you don't like Yu-Gi-Oh with catgirls. Glad I got it as a gift.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Really, this game should win every award.Test of Time: This is a game that's very random, and due to a lot of various luck-based events, no match will be the same. On top of that, new DLC gets released every couple of months or so, and really help add to the game's content.I'm Not Crying, There's Something In my Eye: Man, when QP FINALLY got her pudding back, I couldn't help but cry. Okay, Marc's ending was also adorable, too.Five More Minutes: I could relist the reasons listed for why it deserves the Test of Time award, but I won't.Whoooaaaaaaa, dude!: Admit it, you didn't expect Tomomo to be the creator of the world and everyone in it.Villain Most In Need Of A Hug: Really, in some of Tomomo's cutscenes, the protagonists are bigger villains than her. She just wants someone to play with her...Game Within A Game: ...Do player-made minigames count?I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award: I thought this game was cool before any of the DLC packs came out, and I still think it's cool to this day.Best Use Of A Farm Animal: Marie Poppo. Need I say more?And of course, I could name a million other awards it could win. "Best Multiplayer Game" and "Cutest Characters Ever" come to mind...Really, 100% Orange Juice is a wonderful game, and if it wins an award that would be awesome.#100%OrangeJuiceForEveryAwardEver

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												First and foremost I want everyone reading this to know that if you don't have friends to play with, or friends that you wouldn't play mario party with (for the sake of friendships not burning into piles of ashes), you probably shouldn't get this game. The single player is fun and all, but usually tipped in the ai's favour, which can be a fun-spoiler sometimes. That said, I've played both campaign and multiplayer, campaign to an extent and multiplayer quite a bit, and overall I'd totally recommend this to people who have others to play it with. Pick up the four-pack while it's on sale. Or while it's not on sale, it's still a pretty good deal. Into the actual game, this one is a board game in a party style. There are a lot of characters with unique 'hyper' (character-specific, usually pretty cool) cards. These characters are from Orange Juice's other games, and it's a very colourful cast with pretty good character design. The art style is cute, and the game is moderately easy to learn, save for some confusion if you don't read at least the basics of the game's guide (which has its own option to pick on the menu screen when you select/create your profile, so you really don't have an excuse to skip out on that unless you just want to yolo it). It's fairly simplistic, but in the best way I can mean it. Too much complexity can ruin a party game like this. It has a lot of maps to unlock and check out, and a large diversity of cards, a long with some interesting strategies to pull once you've got the hang of it. Like any game with a lot of characters like this, not all of them are perfectly balanced, so be aware of that.Overall, I'd give it a 8/10 for what it is, and only really taking off the two points for the cheating AI in campaign and the (kind of) tedious process of unlocking new characters to play (which involves campaign). I really love this game, and I'm glad to have it.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												So, do you want to play Mario Party but don't have any friends to play with? Or is it because you don't even own Mario Party in the first place? Well you're in luck ladies and gentlemen, because 100% Orange Juice is here to provide you with gameplay that fulfills all of your Mario Party needs from the complete reliance of RNG, now including cards for you to use on the field or during 1v1 duels between other players and other random npcs to fight against, like chickens and seagulls just to name a few, all in the name of enjoying other people's misfortune. If you like the idea of having a casual experience (with extreme amounts of luck and frustration) with strangers online, then 100% Orange Juice is just the game for you, all for the low low price of $6.99.Okay, so what do I think about this game? Well, it's really a game that I do enjoy every once in a while, but I also hate its guts because of its heavy reliance on the dice. There is a dueling minigame in which each player picks a card from their hand in order to make statistical changes in attack, evade, and defense values. Otherwise, it's still pretty much a game of chance. If you really want to just sit back and "relax" with something to pass the time, then by all means go pick up 100% Orange Juice. If you are really looking for a more complex board game with actual strategy, then you might want to look elsewhere because this game doesn't really provide much of it. Good luck and enjoy the schadenfreude.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												Anybody who is a fan of board games at all, or a fan of ANY games backed by Fruitbat Factory, you are going to love this.First off, you have it's gameplay. This is one of the games that you will want to read the manual for. The objectives are obtuse at best. Basically you have to achieve a "Norma", an objective of collect ___ amount of stars, or ___ amount of fight wins. You do this by going around the board and triggering events to get stars, or fighting other players to take their stars or gain wins. There are also "Enemy" spaces to help rack up more minute wins. You get cards that you can use at the start of your turn, lay as a trap (though you can trigger your own trap! A small but neat mechanic you want to keep in mind) or change combat a bit (stat changes or battle rules, such as battle goes until a KO). When you battle, the person who started it goes first, and then the other player gets a swing. This leads to a neat tradeoff of "Do I go for Stars and risk losing them? Or go for wins and risk not getting them in the first place?" After you achieve a Norma, you level up allowing more cards you draw to be useable, and when you achieve a Norma at level 5, you win.There is reward for playing both Single Player and Multiplayer (more on that later). You different unlocks based on which you play. More characters for Single, more skins and maps for Multiplayer. So no matter which one you do, you get something for it.That said, Single Player campaign, while fun, will leave you feel cheated more often than not. You will feel like the dice is rigged to help the computer win often. It's the same rolls you could get in Multiplayer, but having 3 bots get perfect rolls definitely hurts.Multiplayer is the meat and potatoes of this game. Playing with random people, or playing with a group of friends, everybody will have something to enjoy. It's like playing a good rendition of Mario Party. Are you the person who decides to be a jerk? Or just be a pacifist and watch them get mad after you win by doing seemingly nothing? I have yet to have  a boring game in Multiplayer, and the ability to increase game speed is nice, though it would be a bit nicer if you could stop to see what was rolled in faster speed (All I see half the time is me suddenly do 3 damage.... not sure how).It's also a really balanced game. All characters have strengths and weaknesses. QP is good all around, with a good hyper card. Somebody like Peat has high stats, but low hp and a moderate Hyper Card. Etc. Etc.A simple touch it has is it's music. It plays based on who last achieved a Norma, and sometimes it's worth just trying to play to see who can keep their music playing the longest! The music is also really pleasant to hear, and when you hear your theme come on, it just feels as though you have been embued with some kind of power or hope.Finally, it has what a lot of games these days lack: Charm. These characters are extremely charismatic, and have a lot of personality. It also proceeds to make jokes about itself. "AHAHA! YOU ARE THE MAIN CHARACTER WITH LITTLE INDIVIDUALITY! ALSO YOU ARE MALE! IT MAKES ME STAND OUT THAT MUCH MORE!" One of many lines said in Single Player, and it should show how much charm this game has. Even in the aminations, where you have a character trying to act tough then breaks down when they get KO'd, or somebody like Dangerous QP who seems to dream about pudding while knocked down.In Summary, it's a great game, but best played with others. It has a lot of charm, great music, and is worth the price. Although it's hard to recommend it alone, so if you want the most out of it, play with friends!

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												Its good....like really good if you wish to forge strong friendships or break them like UNO. Alright, aside from the colourful visuals and catchy music which are both great, the gameplay is fairly simple as in easy to pick up and very very difficult to master (emphasize 'very' here).  Its basicallya board game with a fun winning system (either KO your opponents or gather stars to win or you can KO opponents and gather their stars) and has tons of replayability just to get more cards or to try different characters or ways to win. The story isn't that bad either......well.....it is quite comedic so yeah....it doesn't take itself too seriously. However, do be warned that this game is just better with friends. While playing online is fun, the game is overall better playing in multiplayer with people you know because that way all of you can blame RNG for giving one of you so much luck and the other just couldn't get his or her game face on. A solid 8/10 for this game!

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I'll come right out and say it. This game is not for everyone. Before purchasing the game, try the demo. It only has the single player, and the multiplayer is where most of the fun is at, but you can still experience the game before buying it with the demo.100% Orange Juice is a board game featuring characters from games made by the devloper Orange_Juice. Most of the game is played by rolling dice. Moving, battles, gaining stars, dropping stars. Players are allowed to pick cards that are stock piled in the middle as a community pile, so cards you pick can be drawn by other people. Every character has a unique hyper, unique stats, and a unique theme. Cards themselves are either traps, battle, or boosts. Traps are set on the stage and are activated when someone lands on them, battle cards are used in battle, and boosts are used at the start of your turn to give you some kind of power up.The game looks extremely simplistic, however it still looks very nice. Card artwork is well drawn, characters are well animated, and the game boards all look nice. In terms of music, this game features a fantastic soundtrack of 20+ songs, that I actually wish could be bought on steam. There are two DLCs for this game, and both of them feature two new playable characters, who if you just bought the game along with the DLC are playable from the start.The story is delightful. It isn't meant to be serious. A mysterious life form called Marie Poppo steals your stuff, and you chase her to get it back. The humor is spot on, and got a few laughs from me. I do not regret buying the four pack and giving it out to some of my friends. Good Game/Good Game

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												100% Orange Juice is a doujinsoft party game in the vein of Dokapon Kingdom, and the RNG will mess with you juuuuust as much. Make no mistake, though, as this is actually a pretty entertaining game, especially since--unlike Mario Party or Dokapon Kingdom--this game offers online multiplayer where all players benefit from each game via store discounts and early/exclusive purchases.There's a good number of characters to choose from, and their varying stats and special cards mean that each best suits a different playstyle, plus I do love that each time a character levels up, the background music changes to their theme.I do, however, have a few quirks with this game, such as some of the music fading out before starting again (instead of fluidly looping) and some of the graphics showing leftover pixels or being a smidge pixelated.Regardless, if you're into party games or want something to enjoy alongside your friends, this is a good purchase.Final score: B+

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												It's like Mario Party, only even sillier and more luck-based!... Okay, I'll give an actually detailed review.100% Orange Juice is a cute game in all its aspects. Cute characters, cute music, cute mechanics... okay, that last one probably doesn't make much sense. But it is a really easy game to get into and learn, even without having it explained to you.It's a board game/RPG hybrid, and your goal is to reach Lv6 before anyone else. The way to level up? Well, there's no EXP, so you'll have to achieve your Norma. What's a Norma? A Norma is your goal for that level. Whenever you level up, you can choose one of two Normas; Stars or Wins. You either get enough Stars (essentially the game's currency, you consume them when you use cards, gain them from landing on various spaces or winning fights, and lose them whenever you're defeated) or win enough battles (against either monsters or other players). Simple enough, right?Of course, there are also other ways to get in everyone else's way than just fighting them. Even a pacifist who never directly fights anyone can be a dangerous and cunning foes if they use the right cards. Cards are another big part of the game. They're essentially items, and there's a lot of them. Pretty much anyone can use any card, as long as they're the right level and can pay enough Stars to use them. And there are a lot of different kinds of cards. Cards that heal, cards that buff, cards that de-buff, cards you use in battle, cards you use directly from your hand at the start of your turn, cards you lay down as traps... and cards that only your character can use. Their "special ability", unique to them. Their Hyper card. Now it's not quite so simple anymore.Any and all of that can mean the world... or nothing, depending on how the dice roll. It's that kind of game.As easy to learn as this game is, there's a lot to it. It's one of those games that's beginner-friendly, but has a lot of ways to be strategic about it. Or you can just try to punch everything, but that usually doesn't work out so well.The music is really nice. Every character has their own theme that plays when they level up, and keeps playing until someone else levels up. It's good way to remind everyone that you're winning, or that you're catching up to them. There's a lot of variety, too, because every character's theme is a wildly different kind of song. Slow jazz, lounge music, quick-paced techno, frantic rave music, probably some stuff that wouldn't sound out-of-place in a Touhou game. There's a song for everybody, unless you're really, really picky.The online multiplayer is where this game shines. A board game being most fun when you play it with other people? What a surprise!... But seriously, this game is a great experience with others, whether you're playing with randoms or people you know.The game also gets updates every once in a while, adding new cards and characters, keeping it from getting stale.tl;dr: Cute game, nice music, easy to get into, low price, all about multiplayer, potentially infinite replay value. If you have friends who play it, you should play it, too.

												TL;DRGet prepared to have your butt kicked by a seagull & chicken while listening to some sick trance music (character themes)  that changes based on who touched a lollipop. 10/10Extremely cute, deceptively tactical board game. You get to play as cute anime girls, boys, monsters and creatures whom move around a board collecting stars or earning "kills" for taking out your opponent. A Lollipop being your home base which regenerates 1hp as well as brings you to your next phase.   There's an ingame shop that uses game-currency (not pay2win) to unlock characters, colors for your characters, themed outfits (like halloween, christmas) and cards which help you win the game via battle buffs, trap cards, escape, healing, etc. Finally you can unlock more stages using in-game currency at the shop. Quite a light-hearted game, but by no means a walk in the park.I would recommend this to anyone at any age. Seeing as I myself go back to it frequently to play a couple rounds and I find the DLC characters very addicting almost like pokemon where "I gotta have them all" The DLC characters in this game add much needed variety though the non-DLC Marie Popo (whom the community refers too as "popolord")  her stats seem low but she is to be very feared and respected as she will mug you for all your worth with her hyper (each characters ultimate skill) & use you for her own benefit pretty much using you to end the game for herself.  Some fun dlc characters include a girl who self destructs if she loses taking her enemy with her, a guy who rips off his shirt and gains stats from it, a girl whose pretty much a tank and immune to traps. Definitely may invoke that "rage" sense similarly experienced from old mario party games its got that nostalgia going for it.  This is the kind of game that will upset you & your friends but you'll keep playing a few days later. All Hail & Praise Popolord may her hyper be swift and the stars a'plenty. (/ '.')/

												For people who dislike RNG or luck heavy games, I recommend turning away now. 100% Orange Juice is a party game where you play as one of many anime-styled characters from the orange_juice game lineups(Suguri, QP Shooting, etc). You roll dice, collect stars, and beat other people up to victory. You gain cards on the way that'll help or hinder you on getting to your Norma goals.Despite being a Party game and with a simple look, it's actually extremely fun and unpredictable. I also would recommend other orange_juice games to look at, since they're fun and some of them have the benefit of giving you an extra character if you buy them.If you want a fun party game, I would recommend 100% Orange Juice.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26
												Do you want a cute RNG game to play in your spare time? Do you want to be killed by a chicken? How about a duck? If you said yes to any of these questions 100% Orange Juice is the game for you. 100% Orange Juice is a virtual anime board game. You pick your favorite character, go into a map with a selection of cards, which will be used by all players, and try to achieve the five goals (normas) set to win. You can attack other players, set traps, and use cards to try and bring your friends and foes down so you can triumph over them. How to win, card art, panels, characters, pros, cons, and the small details will be the main focus point of this review.At the beginning of the game you’re given a card, norma, and a base. To fulfill your norma you have to land on a base. If the base is not yours you cannot land on it unless you battle someone standing on it or roll the exact distance needed to land there. To battle a character you can pass over them and opt to stop and fight or keep going. When battling it’s completely RNG as your offense and defense will be determined by your dice roll. Each character is given base stats that will either subtract or add to your rolls. If you have a battle card that is your level (number of normas you have achieved) you can pay stars (currency) to use them to help try and sway the battle in your favor. The idea of having normas is nothing new to any game and the system is pretty generic. Complete the goal, base, continue. I personally didn’t find any faults in this system, however, at the same time nothing stands out. The card designs are typically very nice, I’ve only seen a couple cards that I didn’t like the design for. As you’re trying to win the game there will be many spaces you will land on that will change the game. Battle spaces are red and will summon a chicken, golem, duck and later bosses that fight you. The yellow bonus spaces give you free stars based on your dice roll. The blue drop panel works in a similar fashion as the bonus space but you lose stars. The purple spaces teleport you to a random spot on the map which can allow you to have awesome escapes or comebacks. Finally there’s the green spaces which let you draw a card, and the light blue space which allows you to roll to move again. When first playing there is no tutorial to tell you what each of the spaces do, however, the panel art is pretty obvious so you do know what you’re landing on. The panels are colorful and makes the game have a very cheerful and colorful appearance. Trap cards can be used before you move and will be placed face down on top of your current panel unless otherwise stated (Certain characters hypers act as traps to be randomly placed on the map). When a player lands on the trap card they do the traps action and then the panel action under. If the trap card moves your character you will not do either of the panel actions you land on. Some traps in the game are so infuriating that I want to quit as soon as I land on them, others seem really pointless. Each character during the game may draw a Hyper Card. These are character based, each character having their own special hyper. These hyper cards are played like regular cards that can either be used for battles or for map control. Hypers can dramatically change the game, with many hypers you can take the advantage of your allies and gain stars, health, or damage them allowing you to swoop in for the kill. With certain deck cards you can either get another characters hyper or your own, this provides you with a way to try and strategize for the win. In my experience I found the battle hypers to be the most useful as you can swoop in and kill someone and take their stars, or kill a boss. In the game currently there are about thirty six playable characters, some of these characters are unlocked through the store, others are DLC, with other special characters that can be unlocked by purchasing other games on Steam (200% Mixed Juice, Sora, etc). The cast of character all can be found in other games published by Fruitbat factory. If you are a fan of the other games this game is basically a dream come true yet it’s still fine to play the game without knowing any characters coming in (since the storyline doesn’t have any influence or importance in the game).  When starting the game you can play four characters from the start while eight other humanoid characters can be unlocked, as well as the ability to play every enemy character. All the other characters are DLC. While having most character be unlocked through DLC or the purchase of other games may be a turn off, once Steam sales roll around and you have less than a dollar to spare you may find yourself spending it on the DLC.In campaign mode you play the game following whichever character you select’s storyline. Personally, I skipped the story after the first two scenarios. The story means almost nothing to someone who has not played any games with these characters involved. Overall, playing through campaign can be a huge pain but you get a crown as a reward that you can put on your character for completing it all. If you’re into customization it can be a huge bragging right when playing with friends, otherwise, there is no purpose to campaign. There are seven total story paths each having five episodes and a final battle, two of these paths come with DLC. Outside campaign there is Free Play with both multiplayer and single player options. In this you can chose the map, and the field events that occur. Field events can range from drawing a card every seven turns to getting bombed and losing 1 hp. Field events either make your game even harder, or help you. Some Steam achievements can be unlocked easier by utilizing these field events.  Pros to this game:•	Cute characters (And a lot of them)•	Can play alone or with friends•	Character balances •	Spectate system•	Different difficulty settings in campaign •	CheapCons:•	Rage inducing•	The music can get pretty annoying and repetitive, I mute the game.•	Bots do get unfair rolls (not always, unless in harder modes, then always.)•	Profile level can only be raised in multiplayer•	No tutorial for first time players•	Campaign has no real impactOverall, I find 100% Orange Juice to be very cute and fun, and even better once you start playing more with others. I’d give the game an 8/10 because the AI can get pretty unfair, tons of rage, and the music is just too much. (It changes each time someone changes their norma between a track of songs and after hearing all the songs and them getting changed over and over it just gets too irritating.) I don’t think this game is perfect by any means but it isn’t a bad game. I think it’s a game that is worth the original price listed on Steam, and on sale should be purchased by anyone slightly interested in the title. I find the game something I will pick up and play when I don't have tons of time and would like to play without too much thought. It's a game I think anyone with interests in virtual board games and anime should pick up and give a shot. Prepare to be frustrated.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												This is a board game full of japanese weirdo. Basic rules are:- throw a six sided dice- move your character that many spaces- optional - use a card- tiles have different effects - some give you stars, some make you fight some chicken or robot, etc.- when you step on a different character you may fight- the one who gathers five normas (well, strange word for goal) wins - you pick what norma you need to gather and the choice is between defeating other characters and gathering a fixed number of starsPros:- graphics are nice if you can stand this style of japanese esthetics- music is really awesome- you can collect different cards to use during gameplay, thus you can somehow expand the game however you like - setting traps, using instant effects, so on- you can actually speed up the game to super fastCons:- and you should speed up the game to super fast, otherwise you may fall asleep- board games can be boring - you may get defeated and lose a few round trying to get up (first round you must roll 5+, second 4+, so on)- this game is very random - you may be winning one minute and get to the very bottom two minutes later because AI used cards to stole your stars and KO your character- this game is just pointless if you are not into japanese games - if so, go for Talisman or Relic instead- pointless dialogue - take a look at the end of my note to see how it looks likeOverall I give thumbs up because this is a really well made game and I can appreciate it but still I am not into such games thus I'll not play this game a lot more. If you are more into european standards of games then go for Talisman or Relic or whatever (Warhammer Quest?). This game is good but weird and chaotic. ___Pointless dialogue:- Hi Abombo, where are my socks?- I like my ice cream better!- You fight for icecream or freedom you lose!- Popopopopopopokakakkakakaka!- Ok you win, take out your dish and have a cake.I made it out but I hope you get the point.---------- For anyone interested in joining in on completing your own backlog; check it out here - http://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog/discussions/5/530645446320364338/

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												This is a situational game to recommend. Singleplayer has major faults.To be to the point:+ Has a card system. You can use cards you obtain in matches. You obtain them by buying booster packs with in game currency, they contain one random card.+ Freeplay is great. No rigged dice for anyone.+ Online multiplayer.+ Lots of characters to play.+ You can gain levels in freeplay to unlock new characters, and colors for those characters.+ You can obtain new costumes and hair randomly when playing in freeplay.+ Updates and fixes are frequent.+ Avatar system so you can pick a character, hair color and outfit to display yourself as.- Campaign AI have loaded dice in difficulties higher than casual, it can be very bad in late levels of campaigns. (Can take 50 tries to win a final scenario even with "best build.")- It can take SO many tries to get some of the achievements, such as 100% binder completion, or finishing a game with 1000 stars. - Occasional bugs such as: When fullscreen and alt-tabbing, game closes. Doesn't save avatar upon closing game. However, they'll probably get fixed.- FRUSTRATING. (Can be rewarding.)
