number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												100% Orange Juice: The madness of a tabletop game now on your PC! The game plays just as any classic tabletop game: you roll the dice , move the amount of squares you rolled and then wait for your turn. But 100% Orange Juice puts it's twist on the tabletop genre adding many more fun things such as changing one of the core mechanics of most tabletop games. Usually tabletop games require you to get to the end goal in order to win , but in 100% Orange Juice there is no end goal. The map is just a massive circle. This had me really confused at first , but then I realized what the end goal really was. Points. Each level requires you to get a certain amount of points in order to win. You can get points by stepping on blocks that give you coins , fighting mobs such as chickens or monsters and by fighting other players. You may gave noticed a pattern by now , but fighting is another core mechanic of the game. Your attacking , dodging and evading skills all depend on the character you choose. The fighting works just like in any turn based RPG: You attack , dodge or evade the opponent's attack then you attack again. Simple as that , yet , if you don't know all the character's stats , you may have a bad time figuring which option to choose. The game features many unique and colorful characters , many of them being from the developer's other games which means that this is a massive crossover game. You don't need to play the developer's other games in order to get the basic idea about each character's personality , because that's why you have the story mode. I was really hesitant to metion the story mode until now just because it is so confusing and ovet the top , but I'll try my best to explain it as briefly as possible. So one day this guy named Kai drops his wallet on the street and as he reaches for it , a little girl named Marie Poppo comes and steals it. As Kai chases the little girl , he discovers more people who had something stolen from them by the same girl. After chasing the girl some more , you find out that she was working for some kind of evil overlord girl named Tomomo who was behind this all along. You beat her , get your stuff back and keep your new friends. Well that's the basic premise of the plot. The story mode features 5 characters with 5 chapters each but unfortunatley all the character's stories are just retelling of the story I mentioned above but from a different point of view. I recommend finishing all the stories though because some dialogue is changed and so is the ending depending on the character. If you're not interested in the full story , you can get the most out of it just by playing Kai's campagin but you wouldn't get all the cards.Cards are another one of the game's mechanics , each card granting you unique abilities and helping you in battle. There are plenty of trap , battle and boost cards and collecting them all is a real challenge. But if that's not what you came for , you can always jump straight to the multiplayer.The multiplayer is really fun. You can play with up to 4 friends on various stages from the story mode. You can also play with random people if that's your thing but I digress. The multiplayer can bring countless hours of enjoyment out of the game. 100% Orange Juice is a criminally fun game to play either alone or with friends once you get a hang of all the mechanics. Even if you're not into the chibi aesthethic of the game , you can at least give it a chance just for the charm and humor of the characters. Now that I drank all my OJ I can rate this game a solid 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Do you have friends? Do you like a nice board game? Do you like pain loops? WELCOME to 100% Orange Juice.You play a roll your dice move your mice board game, but when you run into other players theres a short battle, sometimes you can play a modifier card before the battle to modify the chances of winning. You can also play a card before your roll at the start of your turn. Some cards can move everyone around, cause you to roll a specific value, place a trap on the board, or place a piggy bank with a bunch of stars.Now to win the game you need to do one of two things. You need to get a lot of stars (the points or currency of the game) and keep landing on one of the home tiles, or you need to win battles against the CPU enemies, Boss CPU enemies, or your opposing players.Now the game can be played single player with 3 CPU players or 4 player multiplayer with up to 3 of your friends (over the internet, sadly no type of couch co-op). There's also a single player story mode where you can play various boards with a loose story for why you are on specific boards, why you are playing against specific players, why the board effects are what they are... It's a wacky time, usually resulting in the persuit of pudding.But be warned, if you don't take care this may be harder than you think, even on the NORMAL difficulty you will encounted painloops with the story, moreso if you do not go to the in game market and buy (with in game money) booster packs so you can get more cards to modify your deck. There are DLC you can buy, and I highly suggest doing so (especially if the game is on sale like it is as I write this review) as some of the DLC characters are fun to play as and the additional cards from the DLC booster packs (still gotta buy them in game with in game currency, which you only get by playing) add some extra fun when making your deck.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												Defenetly a genre we are lacking on PC, the mario party esc genre was never really brought here and most people probably have to settle with emulators and hamachi if they ever want that kind of experience on PC.Thankfully this game brings the complete friend-hating and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t RNG fun to the PC market and I've never had so many of my friends hate me because of it. This game has a random generator system for almost every aspect during the gameplay and it can be both terrifying and completely hilarious depending on what end you're receiveing. I completely recommend this game. There are a few characters that are a bit more powerful that your friend will call you out for (protagonist priveledge) but when you win the game nothing matters but that glorious victory!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												Its good....like really good if you wish to forge strong friendships or break them like UNO. Alright, aside from the colourful visuals and catchy music which are both great, the gameplay is fairly simple as in easy to pick up and very very difficult to master (emphasize 'very' here).  Its basicallya board game with a fun winning system (either KO your opponents or gather stars to win or you can KO opponents and gather their stars) and has tons of replayability just to get more cards or to try different characters or ways to win. The story isn't that bad either......well.....it is quite comedic so yeah....it doesn't take itself too seriously. However, do be warned that this game is just better with friends. While playing online is fun, the game is overall better playing in multiplayer with people you know because that way all of you can blame RNG for giving one of you so much luck and the other just couldn't get his or her game face on. A solid 8/10 for this game!

												100% Orange is a nice and tidy board-game. The graphics aren't that fancy but the look does fit the game very well and personally i like the anime-ish style. The game isn't hard to learn and you can get the hang of it pretty fast. This game is meant for playing in multiplayer though there is a singleplayer mode but in my opinion it's more like a tutorial than a long-term feature.The developers are pretty active and are regularly adding new features and content though latter does cost a bit. But you're already good to go without the need to buy any dlcs if you just want to have a nice and cozy, sometimes hair-mussing time playing.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												100% Orange Juice is a full course meal, complete with:LaughterTearsRegretMisclicksPopo... and more with an excess amount of salt.On a more serious note, 100% Orange Juice definitely is a fun, inexpensive way to spend time with friends. The rules and mechanics are easy to understand, and the quirky themes can lighten any mood. I recommend playing this game with a friend(s) using any chat software, but if you don't have friends willing to play OJ there's always the friendly community.I've been playing OJ for two years now and the game still feels fresh. Not to mention it's continuing to be updated. Mob hypers soon! I wouldn't doubt if they added more characters. There are also seasonal events, like the current unlockable halloween costume event.Here's the part where I tell you the negatives about OJ.If I had to pick one thing that bugs me about the game, it would be the AI.-Online: They're questionable when it comes to some of the decisions they make.-Story Mode: Loaded dice...It's not game breaking, but it is mildly annoying.This concludes my review on 100% Orange Juice.If you're thinking about playing OJ for the first time, my advice would be to not underestimate anything. Especially Jonathan (Seagull).

												This game is stupid...and thats why its awsome.Single player is...um...yeah-But multiplayer is where all the fun is, having the game be so random just makes it that more fun, as you could have someone get stuck in a trap thats not even yours, you could beat a guy thats ahead in levels from you, and the whole thing is all luck and stratagy based.Most people probably dont like that about a game but its a neat spin on party board games and one you can pick up every now and again and just have a fun time with.Also its only 7 bucks compared to most mario party games which are...what, $40?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												for those who want a quick answer before i start this review then here it is: ITS AWESOME BUY ITRight im starting this review right this game is composed of story mode, free play and shop ill start with story mode.Right story mode is you know playing through the story of MANY charactors of this game and there is fairly alot and you unlock charactors whilst playing through certain charactors stories, which you purchase from the shop feature ingame with the ingame points you earn. right the story mode while leave you happy and raging at the same time. The aim of the game is to get enough stars or kills to level up 5 times and win the game you get stars from landing on the star points or battling the other charactors killing them and grabbing there stars. Or you can go for kills which is basically knocking them out so they have to revive the following round. You start as a base and when you get enough stars or kills you have to get back to your base to level back up do this five time and you should win the game, You also get certain cards in a deck which will heal you, kill others or be used as traps to steal stars ect.This is where luck will either help you or get in your way, ever round you move around spaces on a board, yes this is a board based game anyway every round you have to roll a dice and the number you get with the dice is how many spaces you have to move, abit like monopoly. with the battle system it is the same you charactors have there own stats which will add to what you get on the dice roll, what number you get with the dice will go with your stats and deal the damage to the enemy.BUTon the single player the bots in my experience and many other will alot of the time get the best of you the bots are super lucky, thats why i said this game is based on luck and you will either hate it or love it. The bots have a habit of usually rolling quite high sometimes and it will really screw you over. you might lose a couple of times but when you go back and win its the most best feeling ever. It feels like you just done the best achievement in your life XD.the freeplay is basically multiplayer which is the same as the single player story mode except you play with other people on the maps with your chosen charactor and cards you also can unlock cosmetics for your charactors like Hair, hair colour and costume colour, and there are certain charactors you unlock on multiplayer.The shop is a feature where you buy the charactors and maps and colour packs you unlock in story mode and free play, but dont worry you buy these with ingame points which earn through playing through story mode and freeplay.I have brought both dlc for the game and say it is definitly worth it,the two dlc packs consist of two charactors per dlc. so you get 4 when buying both. IT adds to the roster and gives you more charactors to add to the many in the game.THATS  PRETTY MUCH EVERYTHING, i hope you havent turned your brain into mush by now. Overall its a must buy game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												This is a surprisingly fun 4 player dice and card boardgame featuring a bunch of characters from Orange_Juice games! If you enjoy those boardgames that make you hate your friends like Mario Party and Dokapon Kingdom and have such friends to play with, this is a great game. Your goal is to choose a "norma" or objective: you can choose to either collect a certain number of stars or kill a certain number of players/critters, then touch a flagpole to complete the goal. Cards will do a lot of stuff like disable players, steal stars, manipulate dice rolls, force a fight, etc. and they often cost stars to use. Players can build decks of cards for a game, but they are combined and shared between all players.Singleplayer is an unfortunate grind and doesn't get any more interesting until the very end. Since the AI is rigged with loaded dice (what singleplayer boardgame doesn't have these?), it can be a frustrating game of patience with the rng to go easy on you, and since you're playing by yourself you can't enjoy it with friends. So I highly reccomend playing with buddies.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
tl;dr Anime Mario Party that somehow manages to have MORE RNG and yet still be more fun. Use voice chat when playing with friends.100% Orange Juice is a strange beast--it's made me loathe my friends and even question my relationships--and yet it's the most fun I've ever had with a party/board game.100% OJ is extremely RNG-heavy; any game aspect where an outcome can be determined by rolling dice has dice. Explaining the gameplay is rather difficult, but you learn it quickly; I'll try my best to explain it here. The first player to get 5 Normas wins; Normas are achieved by either collecting stars or winning battles, and subsequently landing on a home tile. Additionally, a single card can be played during a player's turn; cards have a variety of effects from allowing you to roll two dice, to warping all players to random spaces. Some cards can only be used in battle, causing things like stat buffs and debuffs, or conditionals like a battle lasting until one player is KO'd. There are also trap cards, which are laid down at the player's current tile, and have effects like forcing players to discard cards, or--worst of all--forcing the victim to exchange star counts. In terms of battle, every character has their own stats for HP, Attack, Defense, and Evasion. HP is a simple number stat, but ATK, DEF, and EVD are done D&D style in that they add or subtract from a roll. In combat, the player initiating combat rolls first to determine how much damage they deal. The target then must choose to defend or evade; defending subtracts the amount of the target's roll from the attacker's roll, while in evasion the target roll must be higher than the attacker's roll to avoid taking damage or else take full damage. Unless certain cards are played, the target then gets to attack before combat ends. Overall, there is a lot of die rolling, hence why many call it an RNG simulator. I concur.Surprisingly, this game has a story; though it's not terribly engaging, you do need to play it as it unlocks characters that can then be bought from the store using your total accumulated stars. Each of the four starting characters--QP, Suguri, Marc, and Kai--have their own story, but they're more or less the same, with only level order being different. Overall, the story is a good choice if you have no one to play with you, but if you always have people to play with you, it becomes tedious as you play it to unlock more items when you could be playing with your friends and having more fun.Overall, 100% Orange Juice is this odd case where it has infuriating amounts of RNG--so infuriating that you wind up laughing with everyone else you're playing with whenever ridiculous things happen. It's a great choice if you have plenty of friends on Steam who can play with you and if you can voice chat with them; you'll have a riot of a time.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
tl;dr Anime Mario Party that somehow manages to have MORE RNG and yet still be more fun. Use voice chat when playing with friends.100% Orange Juice is a strange beast--it's made me loathe my friends and even question my relationships--and yet it's the most fun I've ever had with a party/board game.100% OJ is extremely RNG-heavy; any game aspect where an outcome can be determined by rolling dice has dice. Explaining the gameplay is rather difficult, but you learn it quickly; I'll try my best to explain it here. The first player to get 5 Normas wins; Normas are achieved by either collecting stars or winning battles, and subsequently landing on a home tile. Additionally, a single card can be played during a player's turn; cards have a variety of effects from allowing you to roll two dice, to warping all players to random spaces. Some cards can only be used in battle, causing things like stat buffs and debuffs, or conditionals like a battle lasting until one player is KO'd. There are also trap cards, which are laid down at the player's current tile, and have effects like forcing players to discard cards, or--worst of all--forcing the victim to exchange star counts. In terms of battle, every character has their own stats for HP, Attack, Defense, and Evasion. HP is a simple number stat, but ATK, DEF, and EVD are done D&D style in that they add or subtract from a roll. In combat, the player initiating combat rolls first to determine how much damage they deal. The target then must choose to defend or evade; defending subtracts the amount of the target's roll from the attacker's roll, while in evasion the target roll must be higher than the attacker's roll to avoid taking damage or else take full damage. Unless certain cards are played, the target then gets to attack before combat ends. Overall, there is a lot of die rolling, hence why many call it an RNG simulator. I concur.Surprisingly, this game has a story; though it's not terribly engaging, you do need to play it as it unlocks characters that can then be bought from the store using your total accumulated stars. Each of the four starting characters--QP, Suguri, Marc, and Kai--have their own story, but they're more or less the same, with only level order being different. Overall, the story is a good choice if you have no one to play with you, but if you always have people to play with you, it becomes tedious as you play it to unlock more items when you could be playing with your friends and having more fun.Overall, 100% Orange Juice is this odd case where it has infuriating amounts of RNG--so infuriating that you wind up laughing with everyone else you're playing with whenever ridiculous things happen. It's a great choice if you have plenty of friends on Steam who can play with you and if you can voice chat with them; you'll have a riot of a time.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												100% Orange Juice is basically a simple little RNG and strategy board game where the object of the game is to complete 5 normas (quests) to win. You can also have a max of 3 cards in your hand that you can use. Each card has a different cost and effect and you'll see by playing how they work. You compete against 3 other people or CPU and the quests are either to win battles or have a certain amount of stars. Either way, you need to get 5 completed before your opponents do to win.I'm still not exactly sure what orange juice has to do with this game but that aside the game is actually pretty fun. I started the campaign without knowing the rules or how to play at all, and it took me 1.5 games to pretty much learn everything just by playing. With that being said, the game's rules are simple enough to get used to quickly and there are more multiplayer lobbies than you'd expect. By winning games you can also get points which you can spend in the games store to buy custimizations, card packs, characters, etc.Overall, 100% Orange Juice is a casual little game that I would recommend to anyone if the price drops under $5.Rating: 7.7/10Recommend Price: Under $5

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												100% Orange Juice is the apex of virtual board games. It is the most exhilarating, adrenaline-flowing, heart-pounding, rage-inducing and rewarding thing to come from the country of Japan since the kotatsu. If you don't like anime, don't let the artstyle pull you away from making the best purchase of your video gaming career.While the singleplayer gives some interesting scenarios, the meat of this game is multiplayer over VoIP. Listening to adult men get frustrated and laugh like drug addicts, while watching small girls bouncing around on a disco board to happy-go-lucky music, is an amazing sight to behold for the low price of $3.  Friendships are at the stake, and it's your job to be the cute chibi girl to burn it all down to the ground.|||Let Justice Be Done, Though Lolis May Fall|||

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												It's pretty fun if you've got friends to play it with or can find an open lobby. The method of unlocking characters is to beat the campaign mode, which is a little time-consuming even if you do hold down ctrl + shift to skip most of it. Once you have them unlocked you don't ever need to do that again, though, so it's about 1-2 hours of your life lost to have more fun in multiplayer.And boy, is multiplayer fun. This is a Mario Party or Dokapon Kingdom-esque game that takes elements from both - You 'level up' via stars or wins and the first to reach 14 wins or 200 stars is the winner... Provided they can make it back to a 'home space' before they're killed or worse. There is combat, both against the environment and other players, and there's a decent cast of characters that fit several roles - PvP oriented, star collection oriented, and a mix of both. I've had a lot of fun with this game, and I'll probably keep playing it for a long time.Definitely recommended!

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Wacky fun. That's really the best way to describe it. A 2D digital board game made solely for the anime-girl enthusiast, you and three other players collect cards, gold, and experience from traveling around a flat map and killing monsters and each other. Unfortuantely, the game isn't really self explanatory and it helps to play with friends when figuring out how things work. Each player has a set of cards that they put into the game deck, which are then shuffled and dealt out to players randomly. These cards can either hurt a player by dealing damage, heal damage, lay traps, give coins, etc... The players take turns moving around the board and landing on spaces, which give coins, cards, or spawn monsters where the player must fight with dice rolls. You can also fight other players to make them lose their next turn, or lose gold and slowing down their progression in levels. The objective is to level up to level 5 first, by either killing enough people/monsters to get experience or by collecting coins from spaces and other players. There's definitely a difficulty curve, but the online multiplayer is surprisingly very stable. The art might turn people off at first, but at the end of the day this makes for a very fun game to play online with your friends.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												100% orange juice is a casual card/board game. That has a cute anime chibi theme to it, from the characters you play, to the cards you use.Gameplay: 8The game play here is pretty solid. You start off with a character, then you build a deck of cards that is used in the main game. Once everyone has made there decks the game will start. Once in the main game everyone's decks are placed into one pile in the middle of the current board. Which will be used to draw cards from. So that mean you can draw other players cards while they can draw your own. You'll find your self playing on different boards that can have a different setup each time you play. Each board has there own "board event" from doubling up on Star, cards, or losing stars, to being randomly teleported to a different square and much more. You have 6 different square types. Home, Card draw, star bonus, star lost, monsters, and teleports. most of these are self explanatory. Home is where your character starts the game off at. Home also is used to accept and complete missions also While it can heal you or anyone else for one hp if landed on it.  However one of the benefits about your own home is no matter what you roll if you end up going to it or passing it they game will allow you to stop at your own home and if you do so, you won't be able to use the rest of your movement. Monster squares are two fold. Monster Squares are events where you end up fighting a basic monster to gain more stars. But be careful they will fight back and knock you out resulting in you losing half your own stars. After so many turns every monster square will turn into a monster boss square which spawns harder monsters to take down but gives a greater star bonus when defeated. After a boss has been defeated all monster squares goes back to normal monster squares.You start a new game off with one card that is drawn from the deck in the middle. You are able to get more by landing on the green squares. Some card require you to pay and/or have the right level to use it. While many different card types to be used like Traps, Hypers, battle, events, and boost. Each can effect the game differently while adding more strategy to your game plan.Characters have there own character cards that shows there stats to attack, Defend, Evade and HP while some have card Ability’s. Every character has there own hyper card that is unique to them, However it is possible for other players to take this card from you and use it.The goal of the game is two fold. Either win by having 200 or more stars, or winning fights between monsters and other players. At the start of the game each player starts off at level one. To be able to level up you must complete missions either by collection enough stars or winning enough fights. The high level you can become is level five.Combat in this game is determine by a dice roll on a d6( a six sided die). When entering combat with a player or a monster your allowed to choose one card from your hand that can altar the fight, Keep in mind that only certain cards can be played during combat. The attacking player will always go first. While in combat your base stats will effect your rolls. When someone attacks the defending player or monster they have a chance of rolling either a Defend or an Evade roll. Each one plays out differently. While choosing a defend roll you Subtract your roll to the damage that is being inflicted on your character to a minimum of one damage. While Evading you MUST roll at least one number higher than the current attack number to avoid taking all damage, If you roll equal or less than the attack you will take the full on coming damage to your character. Both sides will be given a chance to attack and defend. However there can only be one attack and one defend roll for each side. There are cards that can effect this however. When fighting a fellow player, if you successfully knock them out you will gain half of there stars into your own pool. After a player is knocked out, every turn that comes they will need to roll to be brought back up, if they fail to get back up the rest of there turn is skipped.Now the bad part about the game play is the RNG (Random number generator) factor. However do not let this discourage. There will be times you feel like the game is cheating you while other time you feel like things are playing out in your favor. If you get easily upset or take game seriously then this game is NOT for you. This game is a fun casual game that almost anyone can pick up and play. And If you don't mind the RNG factor then you might find this game to your liking.When finishing your current game, every star you have collected will be added to your game profile to be used in the store. The store is where you buy booster packs, More characters, Color pallets for characters, and boards. However the bad part about the store is that you must level up your profile to unlock more stuff from with in the store. To do this you have to play online with either friends or random players. It's not much of a big deal really but it still would of been nice to have a leveling up system in single player for the people who are just wanting a fun quick game and not have to play with others. However this is still a minor thing.Graphics: 7The graphics in the game are very colourful with an anime style look and feel to them. All the characters are chibi form. The game has very playful and inviting graphics that is simple but yet nice to look at.The only real problem i can see with the graphics is when you are playing on a board the background has the same repeating design over and over. It's nothing major. Some people may find it distracting or annoying. Music: 8The soundtrack is great mix of easy listening music, to upbeat techno, to anime style music. One thing that can be a problem is while playing the music can repeat it's self over and over again. Story: 3The story is all over the place. There is no real “story” being told here. Every character you can play as has a some what of mini-story to it. The story’s are mostly a random reason to play the game with other NPC's you end up meeting. Some of the reason can be cute and funny.Online: -I normally don't review online play for games. However with how the game is setup it forces you play online to unlock more stuff as I stated above. Over all it doesn't bother me that I have to play online. However I believe a game shouldn't force you into playing online to unlock everything. There are much worse examples out there that does this than this game does.Final though. I give this game a 8 out of 10. While this game is very casual and fun, with no real story going on. It's play value is really high. It may be annoying with the RNG factor however this can be the most fun part of the game of just not knowing the out come of whats ahead. I can not stress this enough that this is a casual game and should NOT be taken seriously. It's a very light hearted game. I can see this being a fun game that the whole family can enjoy(if you have mutable computers, steam accounts and willing to buy this game for each account). For the price it is well worth it. I have spent hours playing this game and  I can say that I have not been disappointed. It's a very simple game but can have enough complexity to satisfied most gamers.I HIGHLY re command this game to pretty much anymore. Just don't let the RNG factor stop you from enjoying this game.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												When I first saw this game, I thought it would be some little game strung together for the sake of it being there.What I found instead was quite interesting.100% Orange Juice is a computer board game that roughly works like a cross between monopoly and munchkin, although it has MANY things which make it unique, at least from anything I've ever played before. Throughout an entire game session, dice-battles and star-collecting (stars are the currency of the game) occur on every turn, but the game is only won once five goals (or "normas", as the game calls it) are achieved, which is determined by the number of stars or the number of enemies beaten. What's very nice about the norma system is that you can chose between either of the two goals, although it should be warned that a norma can only be advanced once the player returns to a home square.With lots of things that affect the progress of the game, it's not a kind that you sit down and relax to as you play it: one wrong move or half-baked thought can be detrimental. However, I wouldn't reccomend this to anyone who wants to have a solid strategy-focused game either, because at times, outcome can be as random and undefined as a game of poker. But for the patient, this is quite a cup of tea, and a great one, in fact. It's fun to experiment with the different elements of the game, seeing which might bring about a more likely (though still uncertain) victory.Oh yeah, and there's apparently a plot to this game. Haven't wasted my time enough to know all about it, but the other aspects alone should provide more than enough to satisfy.Much like a cup of actual orange juice, 100% Orange Juice is a sour kick if you're not ready, but tastes very good once you let the sweetness make its way in, even making the tartness feel like it truly has a purpose.

												This is truly a unique concept, combining card game, board game and RPG genres. I would have given this game a 10/10 but since there is no manual or tutorial it is more so a 9. However, when you finally figure out how the game works, it's loads of fun ( at times frustrating ;P ). It does not have minigames (like in Mario Party), so it is pretty much based on luck (which I don't have, hehe) and strategy. Overall, I loved the charming characters, the card play, battle system and the online play as well. It may seem a bit quirky if this isn't the kind of game you would normally play, but I do suggest trying it out, at least!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Hime doesn't get to have nice things: the movie: the sequel: the saga: the game director's cut edition with preorder exclusives.Now, for my (slightly more) serious review.Ever wanted to play board games? Ever wanted to play board games and RPGs at the same time? Ever wanted to infuse copious amounts of luck into something to see how you strategize around bad luck?This game's got you covered. 100% Orange Juice is a game that combines a stardard dice-rolling board games with a combat system. You and three other players choose ten cards each to shuffle into a central deck. You can draw a card from the deck by landing on certain spaces. At the beginning of your turn, you can either play a card, if it is applicable, or you can move. Spaces can give you stars, take your stars, give you a card, teleport you to another space, or initiate combat with a simple enemy.The combat system is simple: Roll to attack. The other side can choose to evade (take no damage if their roll is higher, but take the attack roll in damage otherwise) or defend (take damage equal to the attack roll minus the defense roll, but always take at least 1 damage). Then, the defender gets to attack and the attacker has to respond. The character you play as affects your final result: Character stats affect their maximum hit points and can add or subtract from their attack, evasion, or defense rolls. Once both sides have taken their turn to attack, combat ends. Don't fret; if you die, you revive at full hit points once you roll above a certain threshold (that decreases for every turn you stay dead).Players can challenge other players that happen to be within their movement range, stopping them from moving any farther and initiating combat with the other player. Defeating a player grants two wins instead of the one win you would get for defeating an enemy NPC.The goal of the game is to collect increasingly large numbers of stars (given in slowly increasing numbers at the start of each turn cycle, called a chapter, or by defeating a player or enemy in combat to take half their stars) or wins, and then landing on a checkpoint space. Each checkpoint, called Norma, grants multipliers to rolls on star-giving or star-taking spaces when you achieve it. Once someone has reached the fifth norma (the colored stars next to your character's head indicates what norma you're currently on), they win the game!Of course, it can't be that simple. The cards you draw can be played in battle or at the start of your turn, if you meet the required norma and star cost (green stars count for one, yellow stars count for ten). You can play an event card that causes some effect to happen immediately, from dealing two damage to a random player to giving a +2 modifier to everyone's attack roll for their next battle, either attacking or defending. you can place a trap card on the space you are currently on,  that will affect the next person to land on it, not excluding you, with something like a -2 to their defense modifier for the next three chapters or skipping their next turn. You can play an effect card that affects only you, such as negating the next trap card you land on or instantly healing 1 hp. Battle cards, played before the attacker rolls, can affect roll modifiers or have more unique effects such as preventing the battle from ending until one side is dead.Each character also has their own unique hyper card. A Hyper card can be an event, battle, or effect card. They tend to have powerful effects, like forcing everyone else to skip their next turn, or allowing you to roll two dice for everything until your next turn. You are only allowed to have three cards in your hand at most, and if you pick up any more, you have to discard  cards until you have a hand of 3.The boards you play on aren't just for pretty backgrounds and their space layout, either. Most boards have events that happens at regular intervals such as Regeneration (everyone heals 1 HP), Minelayer (a random trap card is placed on a random space), or Charity (everyone draws a card).How and when you play your cards, where you choose to move, and whether you choose to fight a player all require luck for your rolls and strategy for your decisions. You may end up being in last place despite your best efforts, or everything might go perfectly for you, but entire games going the way you want them or the way you don't are few and far between. Most games will see you madly scrabbling to recover after a loss, wildly defending your position while you're ahead, and denying other people's victories whenever you can.6+4/10 game, except the seagulls keep killing me.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												Description: 100% Orange Juice a game that pulls characters together from other games that Orange_Juice have created into a single game of crazy board game goodness. This game is basically summed as a board game meets card game. It has a few scenarios for a story mode with some extra/challenge scenarios after the scenarios to round out a decent pure singleplayer phase. The game is prefered for it's multiplay, it's multiplayer is for up to 4 people with cpu players filling in the blank spots and with some fun rewards you can unlock from multiplayer instead of playing the scenarios. There is also a free play mode to just jump in and play some against some cpu players instead of playing scenarios again and again or going into multiplayer.Good: It's a fun game with tons of replay to it. It's great for casual time wasting as well as just something for you and your friends to get together and play for a fun game night. The music for the game is fantastic as well ranging from simple little beats in the menus to jazz and techno/dance for character themes. The visuals are pleasing (if you apreciate cutesy animu). The cards all have fantastic art on them from comical to stunning. Flavor text on each card is a fun read some with refrences to the games they are orignally from to just fun little things. Fantastic thing is for a board game, there is a speed setting in which you can set how fast the animations flow in order to speed up each action in order to not have the game drag on from just waiting on the animations to stop (lots of animations from dice rolls, to card use, movement, and so on).Bad: The game is extremely RNG (like all board games) I am putting it into the bad becasue alot of people tend to rage at RNG and their horrible luck (basically here is your fair warning). Like Mario Party and Mario Kart back in the day, this game can destroy friendships if you are way to competetive. The anouncer can get alittle annoying constantly hearing the cutesy voice call out what panel you are landing on and which players turn it is (mainly because it steps on the music man, so good!).TL;DR: Great little animu board game to get together with friends and play just for the funzies. Great music, fun interesting art and visuals, can be very competetive if you are that kind of player, and VERY RNG!I give it from my own personal tastes as well as the factors stated above,9.5/10 Game as a whole10 waifus out of 10 For Animu goodness12 out of 10 For great music

Posted: January 18, 2015
												Wacky fun. That's really the best way to describe it. A 2D digital board game made solely for the anime-girl enthusiast, you and three other players collect cards, gold, and experience from traveling around a flat map and killing monsters and each other. Unfortuantely, the game isn't really self explanatory and it helps to play with friends when figuring out how things work. Each player has a set of cards that they put into the game deck, which are then shuffled and dealt out to players randomly. These cards can either hurt a player by dealing damage, heal damage, lay traps, give coins, etc... The players take turns moving around the board and landing on spaces, which give coins, cards, or spawn monsters where the player must fight with dice rolls. You can also fight other players to make them lose their next turn, or lose gold and slowing down their progression in levels. The objective is to level up to level 5 first, by either killing enough people/monsters to get experience or by collecting coins from spaces and other players. There's definitely a difficulty curve, but the online multiplayer is surprisingly very stable. The art might turn people off at first, but at the end of the day this makes for a very fun game to play online with your friends.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
Short Review:I've never rolled snake eyes so often before in my life. 1/1Long Review:Summary:100% Orange Juice! is an objective based board game featured an all-star cast from doujin game developer Orange_Juice (hence the title). Originally a single-player only game, Fruitbat Factory has improved the game for its Steam release with widescreen support and HD assets, online multiplayer, character skins, post-launch DLC (with cooperation from Orange_Juice themselves) and continuous updates bringing extra content, fixes and balance changes.What to expect:- Single-player story campaign with difficulty levels ranging from fair to loaded.- A large cast of characters with varying playstyles and unique musical themes.- Objectives: collect stars or just go around punching things.- Dice rolls. A lot of them.- Collectible cards and a myriad of strategies around them.- Risk-reward decision making. This game teaches probability!- Lobby-based online play with a (largely) friendly community.- In-game text chat to yell at friends and strangers alike.- Costume customisation to stand out from the rest.- Chaotic games featuring crippling defeats and incredible victories.- Pudding, strong birds and star-stealing demon spawn.- Valuable life lessons: don't be afraid to fail. And Poppo always wins.

It's a board game where the objective is to hit certain milestones in number of enemies defeated or in amount of stars you gain from doing pretty much anything. Every sound effect is grating after hearing them repeated for 45 minutes straight. Get it if you like card games and board games and anime. Verdict: It's a game

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
Product received for free
												Without looking at guides on how to play this game I delved right into the action and was immediately confused on what to do, so I quickly searched up a guide on steam and relaunched the game. 100% Orange Juice is a mix between a board game and a card game that is based primarily on luck and a little knowledge on how to play the game, this game has two ways of winning to gather enough stars and to beat enough enemies. To move on the board you roll a die, if you reach an intersection you are able to choose which direction you would like to go (After learning the tiles you can get the best out of your turns/chapters). There are different tiles on the board and an action is performed on each one that may benefit your game or hurt your game (Luck based) these include; gaining or loosing stars, versing creatures, Draw a card and battle. I found this game fun to play, however after playing more than 3 hours I found it very annoying how hard the ai is in this game, so I recommend only playing this with a mate who owns the game. The developer 'Orange Juice' used vibrant colours in the game and a refreshing art style that I have not seen by any other dev although the music is great it became very annoying after the third loop. Overall this game was fun to play, had extremely difficult ai, based upon luck, great visuals, tons of campaigns and content and great but catchy soundtrack. Not quite worth 6.99us asking price through for the content in this game however is definitely worth it if you have friends to play with. *Please do note that I have received this game for the purpose of reviewing it*

Posted: January 11
												This game is terrible. It's almost entirely luck. 95% of the game is determined by dice rolls. Games last way too long, there's way too much down time between the player actually doing anything, and there are very few meaningful decisions the player can make on the player's turn. Even the process of starting a new game when you get screwed by bad dice rolls takes way too long. This game is an exercise in frustration.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												Well, I'm not a huge Anime fan, so this is a review based on somebody expecting an interesting board game. Let's get to the point: It is not. You have five different field types you can land on plus your home field. You have cards to spice up things, but for me at least it didn't really make a difference. The game isn't a total waste of time, but it gets old quick. You run around the board randomly gaining stars or defeating opponents to gain levels and thus win the game.I bet if you're into Anime this game is a lot more interesting to play and I might have missed most of the card gathering and deck building fun, but for the basic gameplay it's a nope from me.

Posted: November 2, 2015
												If you ever wanted to make the cutest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ friends ever over the most insipidly evil game in the entire universe, andalways wanted to know what would happen if you mixed AM from  I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream , HAL 9000 from  2001: A Space Odyssey , RNG, board games and everything Japanese up in a blender and put it up for sale on Steam, this is the absolutely perfect game for you. Seriously. It's like the opposite of Mario Party, where the inherent evil of the game mentally forces everyone you meet to be unbelievable cuties and incredibly friendly and want to be your friend. Not to mention, this game has quite possibly unlimited replay value due to the fact that the game will quietly taunt you for never beating Tomomo Hell and not unlocking Tomomo to show off that you have Tomomo to your friends because you will never beat Tomomo Hell because you might as well be trying to beat Russian Roulette with 7 bullets in the chambers.In case you hate yourself but also love not having an empty friends list, pick this game up. You know what, get the DLC, too. And never ever ever in a million years play Campaign, unless you want to learn why you can't say "Campaign" without "pain".Recommended for sadists, weaboos and Hitler.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Funny, entertaining, sometimes infuriating and packed with far more content than you might have imagined; 100% Orange Juice is a mixture of boardgame, card game and dice game that pits four characters in heated battle to gather resources and become the best cameo from games you never played. With boards not unlike those of Mario Party yet sans minigames, 100% OJ is based not so much on the stages themselves but rather in the interaction between the character you pick, out of an available 15 plus 7 DLC characters (more on that later) and a very simple deck of event cards that you can build before each match. While it's a bit complicated to explain, here's the basics: Characters are essentially defined by simple stats (health, attack, defense, evasion and how easy they are to revive) and an unique "hyper power" that all help define their playstyle. Cards on the other hand, and by extension the decks that you build, are gathered into a communal pool that ALL players in a game can draw from and in doing so define the rhythm of the game; hopefully somewhat in your favor if your deck construction was good and you are lucky enough to draw cards that benefit you. In this way you get characters and decks that, for example, are more suited to travel all along the board and gather stars while others are more suitable for walking around and beating up both enemy players and the NPCs that are scattered throughout the board- with both "stars" and combat "wins" being the resources that you need to level up your character and in the process win the game.There's more to it than that, too; like the fact that cards can cost stars to activate as well as require your character to be a certain level before use and that for you to level up, you actually need to land in specific "goal" tiles that act both as base and healing spot for the characters while they make their way around the board. It's easier to understand once you play the game, and do note that there's a demo available, but it all comes down to fast (15 minutes, tops) and more often than not pretty entertaining matches- even if they DO have more than a fair share of RNG involved (mostly RNG, some would say.)So, while the gameplay can be a bit nebulous to explain, what does the game actually include outside of that? Well much to my surprise the game is legitimately full of content and features that are pretty impressive for something that's obviously a shoestring budget game. With four single player campaigns (as feather-light as the one plot for them all might be,) extra scenarios, custom games, online multiplayer, achievements, VAC protection, trading cards and a progression system that unlocks characters, maps, cards and even character customization options as you progress through the campaigns and play multiplayer matches; there will always be something to play for if you do decide to go deep into things.Now, it is important that I bring special attention to the unlock system as it is something that will both draw in some people and turn off others: You see, you start the game by picking ONE character out of four available choices and to unlock the rest you need to play and beat the different scenarios in the single player campaigns. Usually each new scenario is another character that you can unlock and then purchase ingame (with ingame currency, something that you obtain after every single game you play whether you win or lose) so while the game DOES have a lot of playable characters, the choice to keep them locked at the start is a bit of an odd decision that is sure to annoy some. The same limit applies to cards as well, with "booster packs" purchasable in the ingame store and that randomly unlock all the available cards for you to play with. Last but not least, the store also includes certain maps and color packs that are basically palette swaps for character's clothes. It doesn't stop there either. Separate from the campaign and exclusive to the online mode, multiplayer games in turn give you experience points that can then be used to unlock discounts on the ingame store, even more palette swaps and a special set of characters that all have very marked gimmicks and are separate from the "main" cast of the game. Each multiplayer match played also has a chance to reward you with special customization options that take the form of different hair colors for the different characters and ones that can't be obtained any other way. This means that even if multiplayer does have a genuine sense of progression without actually affecting gameplay that much, completionists will probably suffer with the random nature of drops. Fortunately the multiplayer mode is pretty alive, albeit at the time of writing probably especially so because of a recent sale, so getting a game shouldn't be hard.Finally and especially after the mention of so many unlockable gameplay features comes the topic of DLC characters and game balance. The question that most of you still reading this huge review probably have is whether or not I'm insane the different characters and cards are actually balanced and thankfully to that I can say: yes. While the DLC characters are unlocked as soon as you purchase them, none of them are actually stronger than the regular ones but rather they have different gimmicks. The same applies to the cards from the DLC pack, doubly so thanks to the fact that all players can draw and use them as long as one player with the DLC includes them in his deck. It IS true that some characters are easier to use than others and that some need to get very specific cards to truly succeed but the balance is good DLC or not and on top of that game is so random that matches are pretty much unpredictable one way or the other. Do note there's actually 7 DLC characters at the time of writing; 6 available in DLC packs and 1 available only to players that purchase QP Shooting - Dangerous!!, another game from the company that brought us 100% OJ.In conclusion: 100% Orange Juice is one of the cheapest, most unique and most enjoyable multiplayer games that you'll find on Steam as long as you are into the kind of gameplay that it offers. Good online boardgames in general are kind of rare to find, doubly so as proper full-fledged games; so whether you have a hankering for something like it, a pack of friends that dig ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥tting around or even just a few extra dollars in your pocket, this game is a must-have.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												100% Chance Time from Mario Party. Very easy to learn. 4 player limit.Super short review! If you don't play with people, this game isn't worth playing imo.Ok this game is front-loaded with gambling, driven by RNG, but there are ways, like in any card game ever made, to influence the odds in your favor. That can also be altered by the various game boards' layouts, which make the goals of accruing currency vs winning fights harder. Through patience, you can use the sparingly-dealt cards to completely screw over your opponents at the most critical moment, or introduce a number of cards that can harm everyone, including yourself.So that's why the game is only worth playing with other people. The fun of it comes from destroying your friends and strangers, and then accidentally make them win while robbing yourself blind.The single player campaign is goofy, but it allows you to unlock new characters rapidly, the best reason to play it.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												Played this game for an hour and a half straight and could never get past the first level. The game is horrifyingly dependent on luck, which promotes frustrating feelings of being cheated out of victory when playing against the AI. Several times I found myself fulfilling the criteria to level up, yet could not due to die rolls refusing to allow me to land on a Home space, and lost because of it.There is no discernable difference between the difficulty levels (defeating the point of having difficulty levels), and the alleged "Easy Mode" character has no benefits while every other character has significant benefits to accompany their meanger penalties. The cards in the booster pack available at the beginning of the game are mostly just duplicates of the cards you already have (which are mediocre), and since everyone's cards are pooled at the beginning of the game there's really no incentive to put any thought into the 10 cards you pick for your deck.The game's aesthetic and music are good (if a bit generic), however presentation means precious little when you have such a fundamentally flawed game. The devs seem to have barely applied themselves and I have genuinely seen better game design out of high school level amateurs.I recieved this game as a gift, however I sadly consider my friend's money wasted on such a poor product.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												This game is pretty fun. It is a video-board game with a lot of RNG so many may not like it. But if you like fun casual games, you will likely enjoy this. This game is at time exciting, frustrating, and rage inducing. You might be the type to play it once in a while and you'll like it. But if you get really into it, be prepared. After playing this game for so long, it has taught me that trying to win as hard as you can is not the way to go. Having fun is more important than winning. Even if you play 'low-tier' characters that are super fun instead of the 'top-tier' chars you probably wont notice a difference, and you'll enjoy it more.  Also its a lot more fun in online multiplayer. The community is also really nice and friendly, so no need to worry about that. During the steam sales you may find the occasional jerk who just bought the game but those type of people dont play for very long lol. Its also definately fun to play with friends you know as well.Or for those of you who like cute things, a more informative review would be the following:10/10 - Everything is cute. Mega cute.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												OJ has a nice feel to it and reminds me of some of the games I grew up with. I like it. It's incredibly solid gameplay-wise, with impressive balancing. I never feel significantly handicapped by who I'm playing as, except for a few gimmicky exceptions. The card count is high enough to allow for a great number of deck configurations but low enough to be easily accessible. The AI is dumb and gets dice advantages, but the multiplayer community is active and overall very pleasant. I wish there were more boards, maybe even some sort of board-making tool, and there are some crappy ones, but overall there's a good selection.There's an occasional connection issue online, and the DX9 update seems to have caused slowdown for some, myself included, but this is pretty easy to overlook overall.Don't let the DLC scare you off. Because of the way the deck is handled, you can experience a good chunk of DLC without even realizing it, and there's really no paid advantages.Game's definitely worth the full price in my opinion, though I got it on sale. The DLC isn't any gamechanging stuff but it's good to grab on sale.I've gotten a lot of mileage out of OJ and I don't feel burnt out at all. It's a riot with friends and is just a nice experience overall. It sounds stupid, but it's good to have an enjoyable game every now and then which isn't all about blood, guts and murder.Even if the anime style throws you off a bit, as it did for me, it's still massively enjoyable. Turn off voices and you're all set. It's grown on me quite a bit anyway.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												100% Orange Juice is the funniest board game available on Steam for you to play alone or with your friends in Multiplayer Mode (supports up to 4 players per match). Even though it relies heavily on luck, all the strategies and choices made by the player are decisive in the matches. The game has a vast array of well-balanced characters, each one with unique stats and abilities, all drawn from games made by the publisher (Fruitbat Factory) and the developer (Orange Juice). The game grants a great variety of events per match due the combination of cards, field events and dice rolls, making each one (even the singleplayer matches) fun and unique. Playing 100% Orange Juice never gets boring, you know? But please be careful, Poppo can drive you mad.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												CUTE, COMPLICATED JAPANESE GAME THAT MIGHT END YOUR FRIENDSHIPSOK, not that serious, but competitive friends might get in for a fight! A mixture of Mario Party, trading cards and RPG, OJ is an addictive board game that seems too complicated at first, but after some time paying attention to what happens after reading the guide file, it becomes extremely funny! Your objective is to clear tasks (caller "norma") before your opponents do. Whoever clear all levels of norma first, wins the game. Simple? Not so much! The board is filled with slots that will either benefit or trouble you, such as the drop slots, the bonus slots and people can even drop traps for whoever's coming! Not only that, but there are monster battles and a boss can either be summoned by a player through the use of cards or the game itself will place it there -- and they're not fooling around! Although the battles have a basis on chance, it's quite possible to follow a strategy so long as you know the character you're playing with. That is very important when fighting opponents, since they can be far more dangerous than regular mobs!If you want to have some casual-yet-hardcore-competitive-fun with your friends, OJ is your game! I didn't find a single thing I don't like about it yet and the best part is that no one suffers netwrok delay (I'm in Brazil and I play with a friend on the US, so we do have issues with certain games). Worth the full price, even more worth it on sale. I didn't think twice before buying the 4-pack for half the price!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Do you think you've felt TRUE sadness?Do you think you've felt TRUE anger?Do you think you've felt TRUE happiness?Don't claim you have until you've played 100% Orange Juice, this game will bring you to undiscovered levels for every emotion you've ever experienced. The singleplayer is so cruel and brutal you'll soon realize underneath the cute anime faces are demons that feed on your misery, once you get further into it, it gets so frustrating that when you finally do win you feel robbed from the joy because the horrors and suffering you had to endure leaves you scarred for life and cursing your very existence even as you watch yourself fight against all odds to achieve victory.When you're stuck on a level you start to wonder how you can hope to beat any other challenge in your real life when you can't even defeat little anime people in a game of dice.Despite all of that, don't think your only option is to suffer alone, play online and listen to your friends and even randoms laugh at your existence as ninja seagulls and chickens trained in dance by Michael Jackson juke the very attacks you put your heart and soul into only to hit you back twice as hard, leaving you on the cold hard ground struggling for life until the game pity revives you because you couldn't even roll high enough to deserve a revival.When you finally see your friends, the cpu's, or randoms suffer in the anime mario party yugioh dice rolling mayhem it's the most glorious and satisfying feeling you'll ever experience in your entire life, it makes you forget everything terrible you've been through and fills every orifice of your heart with happiness. As your friends threaten to remove you from their lives it simultaneously restores your faith in justice and karma within the universe.Ultimately this game is everything you didn't know you wanted in a digital board game, and an experience you didn't know you needed.88/8 Best game on Steam

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												This game is great if you like kawaii animu characters, board games, dice rolls, and ruining your friendships. The entire game is RNG. If you cant handle the fact youre gunna roll poorly every now and then, leave, go find another game.The game is played by rolling a die to determine movement, land on a bonus panel? roll a die to determine bonus. land on a drop panel? roll to determine how much you drop. land on a battle panel? roll to determine attack. didnt kill the thing and now its fighting back? roll to determine how well you defend, or whether or not you evade it. Also the game has a card system kind of like items, there are draw panels that give you a card, the deck is determined by what each player puts into it. some cards influence battle, movement rolls, inflict damage, heal damage, and alter stars and let you draw cards. Also each character has a special (Hyper) card which is a card specific to them and usually has the best effects.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												So this game suprised me, I wasn't expecting something quite as addictive and fun, the game has some fun characters, intersting and easy concepts and is definately worth the money!The game's RNG doesn't get in the way of being skilled and alot of the games skill actually focusses on adaptive strategy, adapting to the situation you're in and selecting your decision.The game is very fair to anyone, you could put a total noob against a game god and the noob still has a good chance of winning. The game's online play is very fun and playing against 3 other friends whilst chatting online leaves you with over an hour of joy per game of players screaming, laughing and praising/praying to the RNG gods.However, the game still could use a little more improvements, I wish there were more Norma options and whilst the game is pretty deep in terms of what you can do, I'm always wanting more! Otherwise this game is a great game to play with friends or on your own. 9/10 recommend.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												100% Orange Juice is a board game that consists of 20% skill, and 80% luck.  You do have some decisions to make, but fate is mostly decided by the dice.  Gameplay consists of choosing cards that will tilt dice rolls in your favor, choosing your path when you see a fork in the road, choosing to fight or not, and choosing if you want to advance by collecting stars or winning battles.  Although it may sound like you have decisions to make, you'll quickly realize that there aren't too many opportunities to make decisions, and ultimately the dice decide everybody's fate.Check out the demo to get a feel for the game.  If you like cutsey anime characters and games of chance, this is made for you.  If you really like being in control of situations, you should probably look somewhere else.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												Plays like a cross between the Game of Life and Talisman e.g. dice-based RNG heavy board game with character stats, battles and some cards. Not as good as either of the games it's inspired by, but overall still pretty decent. I have no idea what the setting is, who any of the characters are, or what the story in "campaign" mode is about. Apparently they keep stealing some guy's wallet so then he challenges them to play a board game. I assume something is lost in translation.This is not a deck-building game, CCG, European style board-game, or particularly strategic or tactical in nature. Will appeal to a wider audience than most digital board games since the gameplay is relatively simple.Recommended, if on sale. Otherwise, get Talisman, Elder Sign, or Ascension first.
